Desmecht). 1 These authors contributed equally to the work. Mutien-Marie Garigliany a,1, Didier Marlier b,1, Klara Tenner-Racz c, Martin Eiden d, Dominique Cassart a, Frédéric Gandar b, Martin Beer d, Jonas Schmidt-Chanasit c, Daniel Desmecht a,⇑ a Department of Pathology, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, University of Liège, Belgium b Department of Clinical Science, Clinic for Birds, Rabbits and Rodents, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, University of Liège, Belgium c Bernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine, WHO Collaborating Centre for Arbovirus and Haemorrhagic Fever Reference and Research, Hamburg, Germany d Institute of Diagnostic Virology, Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut, Südufer 10, 17493 Greifswald-Insel Riems, Germany a r t i c l e i n f o Article history: Accepted 18 October 2013 Keywords: Usutu virus Flaviviridae Passeriformes Bullfinch Woodpecker Europe a b s t r a c t In October 2012, a 3-year-old bullfinch (Pyrrhula pyrrhula) held in captivity for its entire lifespan and a wild adult great spotted woodpecker (Dendrocopos major), both with neurological signs, were found 4 km from each other and 5 days apart in the Meuse Valley, Belgium. Non-suppurative encephalitis and mild degeneration and necrosis were identified in the brain and cerebellum, and Usutu virus antigen and RNA were detected by immunohistochemistry and real-time reverse transcriptase PCR, respectively. The two cases reported here represent the most western distribution of clinical disease in birds due to Usutu virus in Europe. � 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Usutu virus (USUV) is a mosquito-borne, single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Japanese encephalitis virus group in the family Flaviviridae (Poidinger et al., 1996). The virus is primarily transmitted by ornithophilic mosquitoes among avian reservoir hosts (Nikolay et al., 2011). Prior to 1996, USUV had been isolated from some mosquito and bird species in Africa, but had never been associated with clinical signs or episodes of mass mortality (Nikolay et al., 2011). In early autumn 1996, an outbreak of wild bird deaths occurred in the provinces of Florence and Pistoia, in the Tuscany region of Italy. Mostly Eurasian blackbirds (Turdus merula) were affected and USUV was identified as the causative agent (Weissenböck et al., 2013). In 2001, USUV emerged in the region of Vienna, eastern Austria, where it caused an epidemic among birds of the orders Passeriformes and Strigiformes (Weissenböck et al., 2002). About 10 years after its emergence, USUV has become endemic in Central Europe; the virus was detected in Hungary (Budapest, 2005), Switzerland (Zurich, 2006) and in northern Italy (Milan, 2006) associated with episodes of mortality in birds (Bakonyi et al., 2007; Manarolla et al., 2010; Steinmetz et al., 2011). In sum- mer 2011, USUV emerged in South-West Germany, demonstrating further spread of the virus to the north of the continent (Becker et al., 2012). In the present study, we identified a bullfinch (Pyrrhula pyrrhula, Order Passeriformes) and a great spotted woodpecker (Dendrocopos major; Order Piciformes) with neurological signs associated with USUV. Clinical and post mortem examinations were performed on a 3-year-old bullfinch held in captivity for its entire lifespan and a wild, adult, great spotted woodpecker, found 4 km from each other in the Meuse Valley between the towns of Namur (50.4667�N, 4.8667�E) and Huy (50.5167�N, 5.2333�E), Belgium. The two birds were hospitalised on 15 and 20 October 2012, respectively. They exhibited non-specific clinical signs (immobility, ruffled plumage, half-closed eyes and anorexia), along with severe neurological signs (depression, incoordination, inability to fly, jerky movements, torticollis and nystagmus). After neurological signs had worsened throughout the 36–48 h of observation, the birds were killed humanely. Both birds were in good post mortem condition and had no significant gross lesions. The cerebrum, cerebellum and liver of the bullfinch were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin and pro- cessed routinely for histopathology. In a few areas of the cortex and brainstem, there was multifocal neuronal degeneration and perineuronal clustering of glial cells (Fig. 1A). Cerebellar lesions in- cluded degeneration of Purkinje cells, formation of glial shrubber- ies, lymphoplasmacytic perivascular cuffs, and mild degeneration and necrosis at the molecular–granular layer interface (Fig. 1B). There was individual necrosis of hepatocytes surrounded by small http://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.1016/j.tvjl.2013.10.017&domain=pdf http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tvjl.2013.10.017 mailto:daniel.desmecht@ulg.ac.be http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tvjl.2013.10.017 http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/10900233 http://www.elsevier.com/locate/tvjl Fig. 1. (A) Histopathology of the cerebral cortex of the bullfinch, showing multifocal neuronophagia (arrows). Haematoxylin and eosin (HE). Scale bar = 25 lm. (B) Histopathology of the cerebellum of the bullfinch, showing mild degeneration and necrosis at the molecular–granular layer interface. Clusters of mononuclear cells form perivascular cuffs (arrows) in the molecular layer. HE. Scale bar = 100 lm. (C) Immunohistochemistry of Usutu virus (USUV)-infected brain from the bullfinch using a USUV-specific murine monoclonal antibody showing USUV-positive cells (red–brown), singly or in clusters. Scale bar = 15 lm. 192 M.-M. Garigliany et al. / The Veterinary Journal 199 (2014) 191–193 M.-M. Garigliany et al. / The Veterinary Journal 199 (2014) 191–193 193 clusters of mononuclear cells in the liver. Using a USUV-specific monoclonal antibody (Becker et al., 2012), USUV-specific antigen was demonstrated by immunohistochemistry in the brain of the bullfinch (Fig. 1C). Nucleic acids were extracted with TRIzol (Invitrogen), either at 70 �C from formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues of the brain from the bullfinch, or at room temperature from unfixed brain from the great spotted woodpecker that had been stored at �70 �C. USUV-specific amplicons were detected using a reverse transcriptase (RT)-qPCR protocol (StepOnePlus real time PCR sys- tem; Applied Biosystems) targeting a 91 base pair region of the non-structural protein (NSP) 1 gene (Jöst et al., 2011). Independent examination of paraffin-embedded tissues from the bullfinch by the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut, Südufer, Germany, yielded similar results. A one-step pan-flavivirus RT-PCR targeting a segment of the NSP 5 gene (Johnson et al., 2010) was performed and the PCR product (203 base pairs) was sequenced; the sequence was identical to that of all European USUV strains sequenced to date (GenBank JQ219843). In this study, clinical, pathological and molecular investigations demonstrated that the bullfinch and great spotted woodpecker with clinical disease in Belgium were infected with USUV. The features of these cases were the occurrence of disease due to USUV in two novel avian hosts and evidence of further spread of the virus in North-western Europe, about 300 km west of the 2011 episode in Germany. USUV circulated at low levels in mosquitoes 12 months before outbreaks of disease were observed in wild birds in Germany (Jöst et al., 2011). The probability that a wild diseased or dead bird reaches a wildlife surveillance facility, where a suspicion of USUV infection might be established and confirmed by laboratory testing, is lower in rural and forested areas, such as Namur and Huy, where diseased wild birds are quickly eliminated by scavenger species, than in urbanised areas (Steinmetz et al., 2011). This may explain, at least in part, why the previous European USUV outbreaks were mostly detected in urban areas. On the basis of the spatial distribu- tion of the 2011 and 2012 outbreak of USUV infection in wild birds in Germany (Becker et al., 2012), the occurrence of sporadic cases in other areas of North-western Europe could herald further out- breaks of disease in wild birds in the region. Detection and genetic characterization of tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV) derived from ticks removed from red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) and isolated from spleen samples of red deer (Cervus elaphus) in Croatia O D ( i L T a b a A R R A A K T T R R G C I l D r M w w c v s c e m 1 h Ticks and Tick-borne Diseases 5 (2014) 7– 13 Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Ticks and Tick-borne Diseases jo ur nal homepage: www.elsev ier .com/ locate / t tbd is riginal article etection and genetic characterization of tick-borne encephalitis virus TBEV) derived from ticks removed from red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) and solated from spleen samples of red deer (Cervus elaphus) in Croatia orena Jemeršić a,∗, Danko Dežd̄eka, Dragan Brnić a, Jelena Prpić a, Zdravko Janickib, omislav Kerosa, Besi Roić a, Alen Slavicab, Svjetlana Terzić a, Dean Konjević b, Relja Becka Croatian Veterinary Institute, Savska cesta 143, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, University of Zagreb, Heinzelova 55, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia r t i c l e i n f o rticle history: eceived 24 September 2012 eceived in revised form 12 June 2013 ccepted 12 June 2013 vailable online 10 September 2013 eywords: ick-borne encephalitis virus icks ed fox ed deer enetic characterization a b s t r a c t Tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) is a growing public health concern in central and northern European countries. Even though TBE is a notifiable disease in Croatia, there is a significant lack of information in regard to vector tick identification, distribution as well as TBE virus prevalence in ticks or animals. The aim of our study was to identify and to investigate the viral prevalence of TBE virus in ticks removed from red fox (Vulpes vulpes) carcasses hunted in endemic areas in northern Croatia and to gain a better insight in the role of wild ungulates, especially red deer (Cervus elaphus) in the maintenance of the TBE virus in the natural cycle. We identified 5 tick species (Ixodes ricinus, Ixodes hexagonus, Haemaphysalis punctata, Dermacentor reticulatus, Rhipicephalus sanguineus) removed from 40 red foxes. However, TBE virus was isolated only from adult I. ricinus and I. hexagonus ticks showing a viral prevalence (1.6%) similar to or higher than reported in endemic areas of other European countries. Furthermore, 2 positive spleen samples from 182 red deer (1.1%) were found. Croatian TBE virus isolates were roatia genetically analyzed, and they were shown to be closely related, all belonging to the European TBE virus subgroup. However, on the basis of nucleotide and amino acid sequence analysis, 2 clusters were identified. Our results show that further investigation is needed to understand the clustering of isolates and to identify the most common TBE virus reservoir hosts in Croatia. Sentinel surveys based on wild animal species would give a better insight in defining TBE virus-endemic and possible risk areas in Croatia. ntroduction Tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) is a growing public health prob- em and the most important viral tick-borne disease in Europe. uring the past decades, TBE has been showing an increase in ecorded human incidence levels throughout Europe (Süss, 2008; ansfield et al., 2009). The increase has mostly been connected ith climate change (Lindgren, 1998; Estrada-Peña et al., 2012) as ell as with human behaviour (Randolph and Rogers, 2000). The ausative agent of TBE belongs to the genus Flavivirus, family Fla- iviridae. The viral genome consists of a single-stranded positive ense RNA which encodes a polyprotein that is post-translationally leaved into 3 structural and 7 non-structural proteins (Fauquet t al., 2005). Currently, 12 virus species have been identified as embers of the tick-borne flavivirus group. According to their ∗ Corresponding author. Tel.: +385 1 6123 645; fax: +385 1 6190 841. E-mail address: jemersic@veinst.hr (L. Jemeršić). 877-959X/$ – see front matter © 2013 Published by Elsevier GmbH. ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ttbdis.2012.11.016 © 2013 Published by Elsevier GmbH. vertebrate reservoir hosts, they have been divided into 2 separate groups, the mammalian and the seabird viruses. Within the mam- malian tick-borne flavivirus group, some members closely related to tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV), such as louping ill virus, Powassan virus, and the deer tick virus, may cause meningitis and encephalitis in humans (Gould and Solomon, 2008). TBE is mostly characterized by a biphasic course of clinical disease in humans. The first stage (accompanied by flu-like symptoms) appears 4–28 days after a tick bite and usually lasts 2–10 days. The second stage appears after a symptom-free interval of 1–21 days with a clinical spectrum range from mild meningitis to severe encephalitis with or without myelitis and spinal paralysis (Gritsun et al., 2003; Lindquist and Vapalahti, 2008). The mortality rate is 1–2% in Europe and 6% to even 40% in Asia (Gritsun and Gould, 2003; Lesnicar et al., 2003). Genetically, 3 subtypes of TBEV have been recognized, the European (TBEV-Eu), the Far Eastern (TBEV-Fe), and the Siberian (TBEV-Sb) subtypes (Ecker et al., 1999; Süss, 2011). The amino acid differences of isolates within the same subtype may be up to 2.0% dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ttbdis.2012.11.016 http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/1877959X http://www.elsevier.com/locate/ttbdis http://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.1016/j.ttbdis.2012.11.016&domain=pdf mailto:jemersic@veinst.hr dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ttbdis.2012.11.016 8 ick-bo w e T e a 2 T r T g v V t r i T b P b n t 2 t s f p d e 1 r t r v o f i T r l d t e 2 z d M C v M 1 ( 1 n m L. Jemeršić et al. / Ticks and T hile isolates from different subtypes may differ by 5–6% (Ecker t al., 1999; Lindquist and Vapalahti, 2008). The main vector of TBEV-Eu is the tick Ixodes ricinus, whereas BEV-Fe and TBEV-Sb are mostly transmitted by I. persulcatus. Nev- rtheless, recent findings indicate that in some parts of Europe nd Asia both tick species occur and transmit TBE virus (Randolph, 001; Süss et al., 2002; Lindquist and Vapalahti, 2008; Süss, 2011). BEV-Eu isolates identified in I. ricinus are genetically more closely elated to each other, whereas isolates belonging to TBEV-Fe and BEV-Sb subtypes isolated from I. persulcatus show a much higher enetic diversity. The higher genetic diversity of the latter two iral subtypes indicates a longer evolutionary period (Lindquist and apalahti, 2008). I. ricinus is distributed throughout Europe and may feed on more han 300 different animal species, including mammals, birds, and eptiles, as well as humans. Subclinically infected hosts become mmune for life (Leschnik et al., 2002). During the life cycle of ticks, BEV survives the moults, and it is transmitted transovarially or y close co-feeding of ticks on the same host (Labuda et al., 1997; feffer and Dobler, 2010; Randolph, 2011). Host preference varies etween different tick life stages. Larvae feed on animals of all sizes, ymphs mostly on medium-sized and large animals, whereas adult icks exclusively feed on medium-sized and large animals (Süss, 011). An infected adult female tick may occasionally (less than 0.5%) ransmit the virus transovarially (Lindquist and Vapalahti, 2008), o during an average of 3 years that takes I. ricinus to develop rom one generation to the next (Gray, 1991), the virus may ersist. TBE is endemic in the continental regions of Croatia in a patchy istribution with an average of 20 human cases per year (Mulic t al., 2011). The highest peaks of incidence were recorded from 993 to 1996 and in 2004. The lowest case incidence (n = 11) was eported in 2007. Most cases of human TBE followed an I. ricinus ick bite (Mulic et al., 2011). Since limited data are available as to possible TBEV transmission outes, vectors and reservoir hosts, genetic characteristics of TBE irus and viral prevalence in ticks and animals in Croatia, we based ur investigation on identifying and investigating ticks removed rom red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) hunted in known TBE endemic areas n Croatia that share the same habitat with the main reservoirs of BEV, rodents. Our investigation also included the testing of hunted ed deer (Cervus elaphus) from areas in eastern Croatia where the atest TBE cases were recorded in 2009 and 2010, since published ata show that wild ungulates can be successfully used as sen- inels for recognizing TBE-endemic areas (Labuda et al., 2002; Carpi t al., 2007; Roelandt et al., 2010; Kiffner et al., 2011; Klaus et al., 012). Furthermore, we present the first results of genetic characteri- ation and diversity of TBEV isolates delivered from ticks and red eer in Croatia. aterials and methods ollection of ticks from red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) Ticks (n = 371) were removed from 40 hunted red foxes (V. ulpes) originating from 7 different counties (Table 1), Sisak- oslavina (centroid coordinates 45.7◦N, 17.2◦E), Zagreb (45.9◦N, 6.4◦E), Krapina-Zagorje (46.1◦N, 16.1◦E), Pozega-Slavonia 45.3◦N, 17.7◦E), Varazdin (46.3◦N, 16.6◦E), Karlovac (45.6◦N, 5.7◦E), and Bjelovar-Bilogora County (45.8◦N, 16◦9′E), in the orthern part of Croatia (Fig. 1). The foxes were all adult ani- als, 2–7 years of age (according to their morphology and dental rne Diseases 5 (2014) 7– 13 characteristics). They were shot from the 1st of March to the 30th of June 2011. Ticks were microscopically identified by species and develop- mental stage. After identification, ticks were washed in 70% ethanol and left in distilled water for 5 min. They were grouped in pools according to the fox they were removed from, to species, to devel- opmental stage, feeding status (fed or unfed), and gender. The pool size varied from 1 to 10 ticks per pool. The ticks were frozen and kept at −80 ◦C in plastic vials until RNA extraction. Collection of spleen samples from red deer (Cervus elaphus) Spleen samples were collected from hunted red deer (n = 182) from 2 TBE-endemic regions in the north-eastern Croatian counties Vukovar-Srijem (44.9◦N, 19.1◦E) and Osijek-Baranja (45.9◦N, 19.1◦E). The samples were collected during the hunting seasons 2010–2011 and 2011–2012. The deer were 1–11 years of age (aver- age: 4.5 years), and they were all negative for bovine viral diarrhoea virus and border disease virus (which are members of the Pestivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family). The samples (each approxi- mately 5 cm3 in size) were frozen at −80 ◦C until PCR procedures were carried out. Reverse transcription and nested PCR Prior to RNA extraction, ticks were ground using a mortar and pestle with addition of quartz sand (Kemika, Croatia) and homoge- nized in a buffer containing guanidine thiocyanate (Sigma–Aldrich, USA). Spleen samples originating from deer were also homogenized under the same conditions. Total RNA extraction was carried out by using RNeasy Mini Kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Qiagen, USA). Reverse transcription was accomplished by GoScript Reverse Tran- scription System (Promega, USA) as described by the manufacturer. The PCR protocol was based on the amplification of a sequence (178 bp) within the 5′UTR, partially covering the coding gene of the capsid protein of the viral RNA as described by Schrader and Süss (1999) and modified by Wójcik-Fatla et al. (2011). The reaction was performed in a PCR System 9700 thermal cycler (Applied Biosystems, USA) under conditions described by Wójcik-Fatla et al. (2011). Both PCR reactions were performed in a 25-�l reaction mixture (Invitrogen, USA) containing the follow- ing reagents: 1 × PCR buffer (with 1.5 mM MgCl2), 1.25 U Platinum Taq DNA Polymerase, 200 �M of each dNTP, 400 nM of each primer, nuclease-free water, and 3 �l of cDNA sample or initial PCR prod- uct. The PCR products were stained with ethidium bromide and visualized using a UV transilluminator system (Vilber Lour- mat, France) after electrophoresis in 3.0% agarose gel (Sigma, USA). Phylogenetic analysis PCR products of representative TBEV isolates derived from ticks and red deer were purified (Wizard SV Gel and PCR Clean-Up System, Promega, USA). Sequencing was per- formed on ABI 3730XL (Applied Biosystems, USA) with BigDyeTM terminator kit (Macrogen Inc., Amsterdam, The Netherlands). Program BLAST (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) was used for starting comparisons of sequences characterized in this study with reference sequences in GenBank. Sequence alignment was performed by ClustalW (1.6) incorporated in MEGA5 soft- ware (Tamura et al., 2011) with subsequent phylogenetic analysis and tree formation carried out on the basis of the Neighbour- Joining (NJ) method with p-distances for nucleotide and the http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi L. The red foxes with removed BEV-positive ticks, I. ricinus and I. hexagonus, were hunted in arazdin County near the city of Varazdin (pools 23500-1, 23500-2, 3500-3, 23371-1, and 24559-3) and near the village Sveti Djurd pool 23371-1). All genetically analyzed TBEV isolates described in this study Fig. 2) are closely related to each other and members of the uropean TBEV subgroup. Isolates derived from ticks (I. ricinus and . hexagonus) from Varazdin County were genetically identical, also o the isolate TBEV/1954-Tikves/Cro* derived from the red deer riginating from Osijek-Baranja County. In addition, the isolate etected in ticks from Zagreb County (TBEV/24805-VRB3/Cro) was enetically strongly related to the isolate TBEV/2317-Strosinci/Cro* erived from a red deer from Vukovar-Srijem County. All isolates ere genetically closely related to known TBEV isolates from other uropean countries (Germany, Austria, Finland, Czech Republic). On the amino acid level, similar results were obtained (Fig. 3). owever, our tick isolates from Varazdin County (TBEV/23500- Z2/Cro, TBEV/23500-VZ3/Cro, and TBEV/23371-SDj1/Cro) and the ed deer isolate TBEV/1954-Tikves/Cro* differed from the isolate rom Zagreb County (TBEV/24805-VRB3/Cro) and red deer isolate BEV/2317-Strosinci/Cro* by the substitution of glycine for serine n position 13 of the capsid protein. iscussion While central and northern European countries report a 400% ncrease of TBE human cases from 1974 to 2003 and a further ncrease of morbidity in endemic European countries during the BEV/23371-SDJ1/Cro HE972516 Varazdin County BEV/24559-VZ4/Cro Varazdin County BEV/24805-VRB3/Cro HE972517 Zagreb County past 2 decades, indicating TBE is becoming an emerging disease in Europe (Süss, 2008a, 2011; Mansfield et al., 2009; Randolph, 2008; Roelandt et al., 2010), the case incidence of TBE in Croatia (with an average of 20 patients per year) has been rather stabile (Mulic et al., 2011; Lindquist and Vapalahti, 2008; Süss, 2011). Even though TBE is a notifiable disease in Croatia, there are no or only limited data available on the occurring tick species in the endemic areas, on the prevalence of TBEV in ticks, its distribution in Croatia, and its genetic characteristics. The red fox (V. vulpes) has been shown to be a suitable indi- cator for TBE risk assessment analysis in endemic areas in Europe (Leschnik et al., 2002; Süss, 2008a). In this study, we chose the red fox as the sentinel vertebrate species for tick collection, since it shares the same habitat as the main TBEV reservoirs, rodents, and is widely distributed in TBE-endemic areas in Croatia (estimated red fox population: 15,000–20,000 individuals). Two out of 5 tick species removed from red foxes were identified as TBEV carriers, unfed I. ricinus, as the most common TBEV-Eu vector, and I. hexagonus which already had taken some blood on the fox (Table 3). The main host of I. hexagonus is the hedgehog that has been previously recognized as a potential TBEV carrier and host (Nosek and Grulich, 1967; Kŕivanec et al., 1988). Even though no later papers were published on the involvement of the hedgehog and I. hexagonus in TBEV transmission, the fact that I. hexagonus was identified as a potential secondary vector of TBEV (Nosek and Grulich, 1967) does open the question of TBEV transmission routes and reservoir hosts in Croatia. TBEV prevalence found in ticks in our study was similar to or higher than the average prevalence (0.1–5%) in ticks from other TBE-endemic areas in Europe (Leschnik et al., 2002; Carpi et al., 2009; Süss, 2011). According to our results, one would expect a higher case incidence in humans in Croatia than that recorded, since in low-incidence areas infected ticks are often even not detected (Juceviciene et al., 2005; Süss, 2003). This discrepancy in Croatia could be a result of unrecognized TBE human infec- tions, since the clinical features of milder TBE in humans are often non-specific (Gritsun et al., 2003; Miletic-Medved et al., 2011). Another factor causing low TBE incidence in Croatia could be pub- lic awareness and vaccination that is not obligatory, but strongly recommended. Even though nymphs are considered to be the main vectors of TBE virus, all TBEV-positive ticks in our study were adults, probably due to a very low number of collected/tested nymphs during our L. The positive ticks were collected in Varazdin County human population size in 2001: 184,769) and Zagreb County human population size in 2001: 1,089,145), both known as TBE igh-incidence districts. Similar results were obtained in northern taly where the majority of TBEV-positive ticks were also adults n areas with an increase of human TBE cases in the preceding 2 ecades (Süss, 2011; Carpi et al., 2009; Rizzoli et al., 2009). Interestingly, on the basis of sequence and amino acid anal- ses, the isolates from Zagreb County differed from those from arazdin County, forming a cluster, genetically closely related o isolates from Germany, Austria, and Finland. Prior to our nvestigation, only one Croatian isolate of TBEV had been genet- cally analyzed and reported (Ecker et al., 1999; Carpi et al., 009). However, its origin, date, and location of isolation are nknown. Taking domestic and wild animals as sentinels to recognize TBE- ndemic areas has shown promising results (Labuda et al., 2002; arpi et al., 2007; Roelandt et al., 2010; Kiffner et al., 2011; Süss, 011; Klaus et al., 2012; Cagnacci et al., 2012; Bolzoni et al., 2012). arge wild ungulates are common hosts of adult ticks of different pecies, and as such they may indirectly support the occurrence f TBEV (Rizzoli et al., 2009). However, assessments and eco- pidemiological models have been developed to define the impact f the density of deer versus tick infestation of rodents in defining BE hazard. According to Cagnacci et al. (2012), and Bolzoni et al. 2012), a low density of deer or their absence, increases tick feeding n rodents, leading to the potential for tick-borne disease hotspots. ur investigation included testing of spleen samples collected from ed deer (C. elaphus) from 2 areas in north-eastern Croatia (esti- ated local population of red deer is 7000) for the presence of BEV. Interestingly, a viral prevalence of 1.1% (95% CI: 0.3–3.0%) has een found. The positive red deer were hunted in Vukovar-Srijem ounty and Osijek-Baranja County. The latest human TBE cases rom Vukovar-Srijem and Osijek-Baranja County were recorded in 009 (one case) and 2010 (one case), respectively. From each of 2 TBEV-positive red deer, a different viral clus- er has been isolated indicating that both clusters detected in icks as well as in deer may be found in all investigated areas of roatia. The spatial distribution (bordering Hungary, Serbia, and osnia-Herzegovina) and migration of red deer might allow passive ransport of infected ticks to distant locations, therefore a survey ncluding TBEV prevalence in red deer from bordering countries ould contribute to a better eco-epidemiological understanding nd risk assessment. In conclusion, as a result of our study, we identified the most ommon tick species infesting the red fox (V. vulpes) in TBE- ndemic areas in Croatia. TBEV was detected in the proven TBEV ector ticks I. ricinus and I. hexagonus in Croatia. TBEV was isolated rom red deer spleen, indicating viraemia, even though the role of ed deer in the maintenance of TBEV in its natural cycle is still ques- ionable. The red deer may have an important role in the transport nd spread of infected ticks. The TBEV isolates derived from ticks nd red deer in this study were shown to be genetically close to ther TBEV-Eu isolates and also among each other. Nevertheless, or a better understanding and identification of the most common BEV vertebrate reservoir hosts in Croatia, further investigations hould be carried out including also other animal species, espe- ially rodents, and the survey should be expanded to neighbouring ountries with TBE cases in humans. eferences olzoni, L., Rosá, R., Cagnacci, F., Rizzoli, A., 2012. Mikryukovaa, Nina S. Moskvitinab, Yulia V. Kononovaa, Igor G. Korobitsynb, ikhail Y. Kartashova, Oleg Y. Tyuten′kovb, Elena V. Protopopovaa, ladimir N. Romanenkoc, Evgeny V. Chausova, Sergey I. Gashkovb, vetlana N. Konovalovaa, Sergey S. Moskvitinb, Natalya L. Tupotaa, lexandra O. Sementsovaa, Vladimir A. Ternovoia, Valery B. Lokteva,∗ State Research Center for Virology and Biotechnology “Vector”, Department of Molecular Virology for Flaviviruses and Viral Hepatitis, Koltsovo, ovosibirsk Region, Russia National Research Tomsk State University, Department of Vertebrate Zoology and Ecology, Tomsk, Russia National Research Tomsk State University, Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Tomsk, Russia r t i c l e i n f o rticle history: eceived 28 March 2013 eceived in revised form 9 September 2013 ccepted 3 October 2013 vailable online 28 December 2013 eywords: ick borne encephalitis virus xodes pavlovskyi xodes persulcatus xodid ticks a b s t r a c t To study the role of wild birds in the transmission of tick borne encephalitis virus (TBEV), we investigated randomly captured wild birds bearing ixodid ticks in a very highly endemic TBE region located in Tomsk city and its suburbs in the south of Western Siberia, Russia. The 779 wild birds representing 60 species were captured carrying a total of 841 ticks, Ixodes pavlovskyi Pom., 1946 (n = 531), Ixodes persulcatus P. Sch., 1930 (n = 244), and Ixodes plumbeus Leach. 1815 (n = 66). The highest average number of ticks per bird in a particular species was found for the fieldfare (Turdus pilaris Linnaeus, 1758) (5.60 ticks/bird) and the tree pipit (Anthus trivialis Linnaeus, 1758) (13.25 ticks/bird). Samples from wild birds and ticks collected in highly endemic periods from 2006 to 2011 were tested for the TBEV markers using monoclonal modified enzyme immunoassay (EIA) and RT-PCR. TBEV RNA and antigen were found in 9.7% and 22.8% samples collected from wild birds, respectively. TBEV markers were also detected in 14.1% I. persulcatus ticks, 5.2% ild birds ieldfare (Turdus pilaris) omsk I. pavlovskyi, and 4.2% I. plumbeus ticks collected from wild birds. Two TBEV strains were also isolated on PKE (pig kidney embryo) cells from fieldfare and Blyth’s reed warbler (Acrocephalus dumetorum Blyth, 1849). Sequencing of 5′-NCR of TBEV revealed that all TBEV isolates belong to Far Eastern (dominate) and Siberian genotypes. Several phylogenetic subgroups included TBEV sequences novel for the Tomsk region. Our data suggest that wild birds are potential disseminators of TBEV, TBEV-infected ixodid ticks, and possibly other tick-borne infections. ntroduction Tick-borne encephalitis virus (Flaviviridae, Flavivirus) is a ausative infectious agent of tick-borne encephalitis, one of the ost dangerous viral infectious diseases in the Russian Federation Korenberg and Kovalevskii, 1999). A TBEV infection in humans s characterized by high fever and various lesions in the central ervous system. Mortality of TBEV infection is highly dependent n the involved genotype of the virus. Three genotypes, Euro- ean, Siberian, and Far Eastern, have been described and named ∗ Corresponding author at: State Research Center of Virology and Biotechnology Vector”, Koltsovo, Novosibirsk Region 630559, Russia. Mortality is relatively low for European and Siberian genotypes (1–2%), but goes up to 30% for Far Eastern genotype (Gritsun et al., 2003a). The geographical distribution of different genotypes of TBEV is more complex than their names suggest and can be described as mixed and/or mosaic (Zlobin et al., 2007). For example, the Far Eastern TBEV genotype was detected in the Crimea, in the Baltic States, in the Ural Mountains, Western and Eastern Siberia (Kovalev et al., 2010; Iurchenko et al., 2012). The European genotype was recently found as far east as in the Republic of Korea (Yun et al., 2009). The average incidence of TBE in Russia varied from 1.9 to 4.4 cases per 100,000 per year from 2001 to 2011 (State report Russian Federation, 2011c). Significant geographical variation in the inci- dence of TBE has been consistently observed across Russia. Higher than the national average incidence of TBE cases in humans has been reported in some regions in Siberia in the past years. Mikryukova et al. / Ticks and n Tomsk region, the officially reported incidence of the disease as from 15.5 to 72.5 per 100,000 in the past decade (State report omsk, 2011b). The majority of these cases (74%) were within omsk City, the largest city in the region. Interestingly, the annual BE incidence in the Novosibirsk region located only 200 km to he south of Tomsk has been much lower with 4.80–6.48 cases in he past 3 years (State report Novosibirsk, 2010). An even lower nnual incidence (0.36–1.0 cases per 100,000) has been reported or the Far Eastern region, where TBEV was originally discovered in 937 (State report Khabarovsk, 2011a). These data suggest unique co-epidemiological features of the TBEV foci in Tomsk region. Previously, we isolated viruses of both Siberian and Far East- rn genotypes from ticks in Tomsk and its suburbs. Far Eastern BEV genotype was more prevalent in the urban foci, whereas the iberian genotype was dominant in suburban foci (Chausov et al., 009, 2010). The principal vectors and hosts for TBEV in Tomsk and ther regions in Siberia are I. persulcatus ticks and small rodents, espectively. However, in the urban landscapes, it has recently been hown that I. pavlovskyi ticks are predominant and may support BEV circulation in the city (Romanenko, 2011; Romanenko and ondrat’eva, 2011). Interestingly, I. pavlovskyi ticks feed mainly on ild birds at all stages of their life cycle suggesting that birds may e involved in the eco-epidemiology of TBEV (Bolotin et al., 1977). To determine the role of wild birds in the circulation and spread f TBEV in urban and suburban foci in Tomsk, we studied samples rom wild birds and individual ticks collected from 2006 to 2011 or the presence of TBEV markers (viral RNA and antigen). aterials and methods ild bird and tick sampling In May to August in 2006–2011, wild birds were captured in 3 ypes of locations: urban landscapes (Stadium, University Grove, outhern graveyard); suburban settings (TNHZ, Kolarovo); rural nd forest areas (Haldeevo, Maloyksinskyi), as previously described Moskvitina et al., 2008). The capture of and experiments with wild irds were done in accordance with the permits 70 no. 024401 and 0 no. 024399 from the local government and regulations for work- ng with wild animals. The ticks (adults, nymphs, and larvae) were ollected from captured wild birds. The identification of tick and ird species was carried out as recommended by zoological taxo- omic guides (Ryabitsev, 2001; Filippova, 1997). Ticks were stored t −70 ◦C until nucleic acid extraction and virus isolation. RT-PCR ith primers specific to tick mitochondrial DNA was also used to dentify tick species. etection of TBEV markers TBEV antigens were detected by means of the immune-enzyme nalysis as previously described (Ternovoi et al., 2007). Briefly, viral ntigen was captured on the surface of 96-well polystyrene plates rom 10% homogenates of ticks and internal organs of birds with onoclonal antibodies 10H10 against protein E of TBEV. Immune omplexes were detected by EB1 monoclonal antibody against rotein E of TBEV labeled with biotin, which was revealed by avidin- eroxidase. RNA extraction, reverse transcription, and detection of BEV cDNA by RT-PCR was done as described previously (Chausov t al., 2009, 2010). irus isolation Tick homogenates diluted 1:10 were used to infect PKE (pig kid- ey embryo) cells. The infected cells were incubated at 37 ◦C for days in Eagle MEM medium supplemented with 2% fetal bovine orne Diseases 5 (2014) 145– 151 serum. The cell culture supernatant was used to infect the next pas- sage of PKE cells. The viral RNA for sequencing was purified from infected PKE cells after the 5th passage. Sequencing of PCR products, structural and phylogenetic analysis RT-PCR products were separated in 1.5% agarose gel and gel-purified using Wizard SV Gel and PCR Clean-Up System kit (Promega, USA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Sequencing was performed using CEQ DTCS Kit (Beckman-Coulter, Cat# 608000, USA) on Beckman Coulter CEQ2000 XL genetic analyzer according to the manufacturer’s instructions. All sam- ples were analyzed twice in independent experiments. Multiple sequence alignment and phylogenetic studies were performed using Vector NTI Suite 10.0 (www.invitrogen.com) and MEGA 5 (Tamura et al., 2011). Results Ticks collected from wild birds In the course of the study, we captured 779 wild birds and col- lected 841 larval, nymphal, and adult ixodid ticks from these birds, 244 I. persulcatus, 531 I. pavlovskyi, and 66 I. plumbeus. The max- imum number of collected ticks from one fieldfare (Turdus pilaris Linnaeus, 1758) was 70 ticks including 19 larvae, 33 nymphs, and 18 adults. The list of captured bird species with all stages of ixodid ticks is presented in Table 1. In summary, we collected 3 species of ticks from captured wild birds: I. persulcatus, I. pavlovskyi, and I. plumbeus. The birds we captured in suburban locations were pre- dominantly carrying I. persulcatus, whereas the urban birds mostly carried I. pavlovskyi. Ixodes plumbeus were found only on the sand martins. Ticks (all stages) were found from early May until mid August on birds with maximum numbers in June and July. Most frequently, we found larvae and nymphs – 47.9% and 37.7%, respec- tively. Adults constituted only 14.4%. Different stages of ticks (in various combinations) on a single bird were found in 46.2% of birds. Detection of TBEV markers To determine the prevalence of TBEV in wild birds, we analyzed 489 wild-bird samples, collected from May until mid August, for TBEV infection, for viral antigen and RNA. We found TBEV markers in 40 bird species out of 60 species tested. The prevalence of TBEV markers (RNA and antigen) in TBEV-positive bird species ranged from 14% to 63% with a very significant month-to-month and year- to-year fluctuation. On average, among TBEV-positive bird species, 9.7% of the individuals were found to be positive for viral RNA and 22.8% for viral antigen. The highest prevalences (>50%) of TBEV markers were found in fieldfares, common redstarts, and brambling birds, which could be explained by their relatively frequent contact with infected ticks and a more or less high individual susceptibility of these birds to TBEV. To determinate the prevalence of TBEV markers in ixodid ticks collected from wild birds in TBEV foci, we studied 466 individual ticks (larvae, nymphs, adults). Specifically, we analyzed 71 I. persul- catus, 324 I. рavlovskyi, and 71 I. plumbeus ticks. Both TBEV RNA and antigen were found in 14.1% of I. persulcatus, 5.2% of I. рavlovskyi, and 4.2% of I. plumbeus ticks. We found TBEV-positive I. persulcatus larvae on the common redstart and the tree pipit and I. pavlovskyi larvae only on the fieldfare. TBEV-positive I. persulcatus nymphs were found on the fieldfare, the redwing, the Eurasian tree spar- row, and the tree pipit, and I. pavlovskyi nymphs on the fieldfare, the redwing, the Eurasian tree sparrow, and the tree pipit. Most of TBEV-positive ticks (larvae and nymphs) were collected from field- fares and redwings (11 from 17). However, no infected I. plumbeus http://www.invitrogen.com/ T.P. Generally, the prevalence of TBEV arkers in I. plumbeus ticks was lower than in other ixodid ticks. haracterization of the TBEV isolated from wild birds and ixodid icks We isolated 2 strains of TBEV designated as Tms B08-12 and ms B08-14 (GenBank KC602117 and KC602118) on PKE cells from eldfare and Blyth’s reed warbler. All other attempts to isolate ny viral strains from TBEV-positive samples on PKE cells failed. e used total viral RNA from Tms B08-12 and Tms B08-14 virus s well as viral cDNA fragments from 20 RT-PCR-positive individ- al ticks and 10 birds to determine viral sequences of the 5′-NCR f the viral genome for phylogenetic analysis as described previ- usly (Chausov et al., 2009, 2010). Eleven TBEV sequences were btained from I. рavlovskyi ticks and 9 sequences from I. persulcatus icks. The phylogenetic analysis of 5′-NCR sequences is presented in ig. 1. We found 23 isolates of the Far Eastern genotype and 9 of the iberian genotype. Both isolated TBEV strains Tms B08-12 and Tms 08-14 from birds belonged to the Far Eastern genotype. The Far astern sequences from birds and ticks segregate into several puta- ive subclusters. Two subclusters grouped with the well-known rototype strains Glubinnoe/2004 and 205. We found Glubinnoe- ike isolates in samples from ticks and wild birds. The sequences of he Siberian genotype isolates segregated into 3 putative subclus- ers: Zausaev-like, Kolarovo-like, and a third unique subcluster. The ausaev-like sequences isolated from ticks and wild birds were very imilar to the human isolate Zausaev (1983) from a patient with ethal chronic TBEV infection (Gritsun et al., 2003b). The Kolarovo- ike sequences in this study were isolated from wild birds, and the BEV strain Kolarovo-2008 was isolated from an I. pavlovskyi tick in he study site Kolarovo (Chausov et al., 2011). The c37-2 and 220308 equences from I. persulcatus ticks were unique and did not clus- er with any other Siberian strains of TBEV. The same is true for he Tms 10–18 isolate (from I. pavlovskyi). This isolate is a possible andidate for a new subcluster within the Siberian genotype. In summary, we discovered a high genetic biodiversity of TBEV nd novel TBEV sequences in wild birds and ixodid ticks in Tomsk egion for 2 main genotypes of TBEV. We propose that circulation f TBEV between wild birds and ixodid ticks is a possible driving actor for the often high TBEV variability in highly endemic TBEV oci. iscussion The role of wild birds in the transmission of flaviviruses is ell documented for several mosquito-borne flaviviruses such as est Nile, Japanese encephalitis, and Usutu viruses (Hubálek, 2004; siodras et al., 2008; Lelli et al., 2008). TBEV as a tick-borne fla- ivirus is most often transmitted by I. ricinus ticks in Europe and . persulcatus in northern Asia (Gritsun et al., 2003a). Previously, 6 pecies of ixodid ticks such as Dermacentor reticulatus Fabr., 1794 D. pictus); the taiga tick, I. persulcatus P. Sch., 1930; I. pavlovskyi om., 1946; I. trianguliceps Bir., 1901; I. plumbeus Leach. 1815; nd Haemaphysalis concinna Koch 1844 were reported as vectors or TBEV in Tomsk foci (Romanenko, 2004, 2009). Usually, only I. avlovskyi, I. persulcatus, and D. reticulatus ticks attack humans. he other species of ixodid ticks (I. trianguliceps, I. plumbeus, H. oncinna) have not been reported to attack humans probably ecause of their low abundance and close association with their ain hosts. The TBEV usually circulates in natural foci between ticks and mall mammals (Gritsun et al., 2003a). The role of wild birds in he spread and circulation of TBEV is not well defined. It was orne Diseases 5 (2014) 145– 151 suggested that wild birds participate in TBEV circulation in the nat- ural foci of Tomsk region 50–60 years ago (Fedorov, 1958). Since then, dissemination of ticks infected with TBEV and/or other tick- borne pathogens by wild birds has been described in several other regions (Hubálek, 2004; Waldenström et al., 2007; Kempf et al., 2011; Dietrich et al., 2011; Movila et al., 2013). Moreover, TBEV viremia was demonstrated in mallards after experimental infection and thereby also their potential involvement in TBEV circulation in nature (van Tongeren, 1983). TBEV spread by migratory birds was also hypothesized by Suzuki et al. (2007) based on the phyloge- netic analysis of TBEV sequences. They proposed that Far Eastern TBEV was exported to Japanese islands by migratory birds from continental regions of Far Eastern Russia. The prevalence of TBEV markers in ixodid ticks varied broadly depending on the month of tick collection, the life stage of ticks, and weather conditions. Prevalence was found to range from 5.7% to 7.5% in I. pavlovskyi and I. persulcatus ticks (all stages) randomly collected in Tomsk and its suburbs (Chausov et al., 2010). These figures are generally consistent with our data on the finding of TBEV markers in ticks collected from wild birds. The high inci- dence of tick-borne infections in Tomsk region correlates with the very high frequency of tick attacks on humans. The cardinal fea- ture of the current eco-epidemiological situation in Tomsk is the high abundance of I. pavlovskyi ticks and their apparent spread sup- ported by wild birds living in suburban and urban environments. A similar situation was recently reported for Novosibirsk and its suburbs (Livanova et al., 2012; Malkova et al., 2012). Our study com- plements these reports confirming the importance of wild birds for the spread of I. pavlovskyi ticks in and around large cities in Siberia. We used RT-PCR for the detection of TBEV RNA and EIA for the detection of TBEV antigen in tick and wild-bird samples. Viral antigen was detected more frequently than viral RNA. The high effi- ciency of antigen-capture EIA for detection of flaviviruses in field samples was previously demonstrated for dengue and Japanese encephalitis virus in swine, human, and mosquito samples (Duong et al., 2011; Voge et al., 2013; Mei et al., 2012). We, too, found that antigen-capture EIA is suitable for analysing tick homogenates (Chausov et al., 2009, 2010). The genetic markers of several infections such as West Nile virus, Borrelia spp., Rickettsia spp., Ehrlichia spp. were also previ- ously detected in ixodid ticks collected in Tomsk foci (Chausov et al., 2009). Other studies suggested that migratory birds are involved in the spreading of tick-borne infections such as Rickettsia spp., Bor- relia spp., Babesia spp., and possibly also the European genotype of TBEV (Hamer et al., 2012a,b; Dietrich et al., 2011; Marsot et al., 2012; Movila et al., 2011, 2013). Together with our data, these stud- ies suggest a possible role of wild birds in the dissemination of TBEV and other tick-borne infections that warrant further investigation. We surveyed 779 captured wild birds and found ixodid ticks on 19 species of birds. Multiple contacts of fieldfares with I. persulcatus and/or I. pavlovskyi ticks were found with captured birds bearing 6 ixodid ticks on average. Taking into account the period of activity of ixodid ticks in this region and their feeding time on birds, we can estimate that one fieldfare may be in contact with approximately 60–120 ticks within one endemic season. Thus, the probability of multiple contacts between fieldfares and TBEV-infected I. persul- catus and/or I. pavlovskyi ticks within one endemic season appears very high. The relatively long lifespan of these birds (approximately 18 years) together with the high population size both in urban and suburban environments makes the contact of the birds with the virus virtually inevitable (Ravkin and Ravkin, 2005). The find- ing of TBEV markers in other species of birds suggests that several species of birds are involved in the circulation of TBEV during the high tick activity season. The nomadic and migratory activities f the birds throughout Europe and Asia, their high densities in uburban areas and large cities suggests that wild birds may be mplicated in (i) spreading of TBEV and other tick-borne infections y carrying infected ticks; (ii) transportation of ixodid ticks (over hort and long distances) to new biotopes; (iii) establishing tick- orne infection foci in and around large cities; (iv) supporting TBEV iodiversity in highly endemic TBEV foci. Sequencing of 5′-NCR of TBEV and phylogenetic analyses howed also that the Far Eastern genotype was dominant in stud- ed birds and tick samples. Similar results were obtained previously hen the Far Eastern genotype was predominantly found in ticks ollected in Tomsk city, whereas the Siberian genotype was pre- ominantly found in ticks in suburban foci (Chausov et al., 2009, 010). We were able to isolate and sequence genomic fragments f the 2 newly isolated TBEV strains Tms B08-12 and Tms B08- 4 from wild birds. Notably, viral isolates and RNA isolates from ild birds clustered with TBEV strain Glubinnoe/2004 in phylo- enetic analyses. This strain was isolated from fulminant lethal uman cases in the Far Eastern region of Russia. Rapid replication n PKE cells and a high level of infectious virion production are the ajor differences between Glubinnoe/2004 and other TBEV strains Ternovoi et al., 2007). The high level of homology between 5′-NCR f the TBEV variants from wild birds and Glubinnoe/2004 suggests hat the highly effective replication is typical for the isolated TBEV trains. Importantly, this is the first isolation of Glubinnoe/2004- ike TBEV strains outside the Far Eastern region of Russia. TBEV trains isolated in China Senzhang and MDJ01 as well as other Chi- ese strains belong to the Far-Eastern subtype (Zhang et al., 2012; u et al., 2013). These strains cluster with common Russian Far astern strains such as Glubinnoe/2004, Kavalerovo, Svetlogorie, rimorye-52 in cluster III, Senzhang-like TBEV strains (Leonova t al., 2013). These molecular epidemiological data suggest that Far astern, Chinese, and Siberian TBEV have a similar coevolution and issemination in these geographic regions. The role of wild birds in BEV dissemination, even though appealing, remains hypothetical. nfortunately, we could find only fragmentary reports (bird ring essages) of possible seasonal migration of birds in the triangle ar East–China–Siberia. The fast dissemination of avian influenza H5N1) from China to Siberia by wild birds (Shestopalov et al., 2006) as shown that transmission of TBEV (Far Eastern genotype) by wild ird is possible. The isolation of TBEV strains from fieldfares indicates that a per- istent presence of the virus is possible in this species of birds. his is also indirectly supported by the following: (a) detection f TBEV antigen and RNA as well as live virus in these birds; (b) etection of TBEV markers and virus in ixodid ticks collected from irds; (c) the large size of populations of wild birds and ixodid ticks n Western Siberia. Additionally, TBEV persistence in wild birds s indirectly supported by proliferation of TBEV in different cell ultures and its potential to cause chronic forms of TBEV infec- ion (Gritsun et al., 2003b). The duration of TBEV persistence in ild birds remains unknown. However, the closely related West ile virus (WNV) is capable of persisting for more than 12 weeks n birds (Wheeler et al., 2012). If the time of TBEV persistence in ild birds is similar to that of WNV, the distance of spreading BEV and possibly also other tick-borne infections by birds could be ong. In this study, we confirm the involvement of wild birds in the for- ation of natural foci of TBEV in Tomsk in 2006–2011. We propose hat wild birds, particularly fieldfares, are potential disseminators or quick dissemination of Far Eastern and Siberian genotypes of BEV, for TBEV-infected ixodid ticks, and possibly other tick-borne nfections over short and perhaps also long distances. orne Diseases 5 (2014) 145– 151 Disclosure statement The authors have no commercial associations that might create a conflict of interest in connection with the manuscript enti- tled “Surveillance of tick-borne encephalitis virus in wild birds and ticks in Tomsk City and its suburbs (Western Siberia)”. Confirmed case of encephalitis caused by Murray Valley encephalitis virus infection in a horse Journal of Veterinary Diagnostic Investigation 24(2) 431 –436 © 2012 The Author(s) Reprints and permission: sagepub.com/journalsPermissions.nav DOI: 10.1177/1040638711433325 http://jvdi.sagepub.com Murray Valley encephalitis virus (MVEV; family Flaviviri- dae, genus Flavivirus) is an important human pathogen. The principal vector is the freshwater mosquito Culex annuliros- tris.16 The virus is considered to be endemic in northern Australia and is periodically reactivated or reintroduced into southern and eastern Australia, but the epidemiology is complex, involving the interplay of vertebrate host, vector, and environmental factors. Although infections occur in a variety of vertebrate hosts, amplification is thought to occur principally in wild birds (waders), especially the Nankeen night heron (Nycticorax caledonicus).16 Horses are known to be susceptible to a number of mosquito-borne flaviviral encephalitides, including infec- tions by West Nile virus (WNV) and Japanese encephalitis virus.17 Kunjin virus, a subtype of WNV,9 has been implicated as the cause of a single case of naturally occurring encephalo- myelitis in a horse from the state of Victoria in Australia.1 MVEV is known to infect horses, based on serological evi- dence,7 and there is considerable anecdotal evidence to suggest the virus can cause neurological disease.22 Experimental infections of horses with MVEV have had varied outcomes, depending on the dosage and route of inoculation. Intracerebral challenge with high doses of virus has produced encephalitis in horses.7,18 Small doses of peripherally inoculated MVEV have either failed to pro- duce infections7 or have resulted in short-lived viremia and mild, transient clinical signs.13 The current report describes a case of severe, naturally occurring encephalomyelitis in a horse, attributed to MVEV. During April 2008, a 5-year-old Australian stock horse mare from Monto, Queensland, Australia (24°52′S, 151°07′E) developed neurological signs. When examined by the veteri- narian on day 1, the horse was in a mildly stuporous state but could be roused by stimulation. Mild ataxia and forelimb pro- prioceptive deficits were noted. Appetite was depressed, but vital signs were normal. Treatment with parenterala and oralb nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories was instigated. By day 3, there was a degree of facial paralysis, affecting the upper and lower lips but not the eyelids. By day 6, the horse was later- ally recumbent and unable to lift its head. At this stage, the horse was euthanized with a barbituratec overdose, and a field necropsy was conducted. The only abnormality noted at nec- ropsy was brain swelling, which decreased after the dura mater was opened. 433325 XXXXXX10.1177/1040638711433325Gord on et al.Encephalitis caused by Murray Valley encephalitis virus From the Biosecurity Sciences Laboratory, Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation, Coopers Plains, Queensland, Australia (Gordon, Oakey); All Creatures Vet Services, Monto, Queensland, Australia (Marbach); Tropical and Aquatic Animal Health Laboratory, Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation, Townsville, Queensland, Australia (Edmunds, Condon); School of Biomedical Sciences, Curtin University, Bentley, Western Australia, Australia (Diviney, Williams); and Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong, Victoria, Australia (Bingham). 1Corresponding Author: Anita N. Gordon, Biosecurity Sciences Laboratory, Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation, PO Box 156, Archerfield BC, Queensland 4108, Australia. anita.gordon@deedi.qld.gov.au Confirmed case of encephalitis caused by Murray Valley encephalitis virus infection in a horse Anita N. Gordon,1 Cameron R. Marbach, Jane Oakey, Glen Edmunds, Kelly Condon, Sinead M. Diviney, David T. Williams, John Bingham Abstract. A 5-year-old Australian stock horse in Monto, Queensland, Australia, developed neurological signs and was euthanized after a 6-day course of illness. Histological examination of the brain and spinal cord revealed moderate to severe subacute, nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis. Sections of spinal cord stained positively in immunohistochemistry with a flavivirus-specific monoclonal antibody. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction assay targeting the envelope gene of flavivirus yielded positive results from brain, spinal cord, cerebrospinal fluid, and facial nerve. A flavivirus was isolated from the cerebrum and spinal cord. Nucleotide sequences obtained from amplicons from both tissues and virus isolated in cell culture were compared with those in GenBank and had 96–98% identity with Murray Valley encephalitis virus. The partial envelope gene sequence of the viral isolate clustered into genotype 1 and was most closely related to a previous Queensland isolate. Key words: Encephalitis; flavivirus; horses; Murray Valley encephalitis virus. http://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.1177%2F1040638711433325&domain=pdf&date_stamp=2012-02-29 432 Gordon et al. Tissues, including brain and cervical spinal cord, were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin, and then paraffin embedded, sectioned at 5 µm, and stained with hematoxylin and eosin, using standard techniques. Histology revealed moderate to severe subacute, nonsuppurative encephalomy- elitis. Changes were more severe in the hippocampus, mid- brain, medulla, and cervical spinal cord than in the cerebrum. The minimum change at all levels of the brain was perivas- cular cuffs in both gray and white matter. Cuffs were of vari- able thickness and consisted of a mixture of lymphocytes and histiocytes (Fig. 1). In the spinal cord, severe inflamma- tion was largely restricted to the gray matter (Fig. 2). Diffuse and focal gliosis were present throughout the brain and spinal cord. In the more severely affected areas of midbrain and medulla, swollen, chromatolytic, and necrotic neurons were present, with glial satellitosis (Fig. 3). There were occa- sional small foci of hemorrhage and malacia in the cerebral white matter, medulla, and spinal cord (Fig. 2). There was also mild nonsuppurative meningitis. No abnormalities were detected in other tissues. Sections of cerebrum, brain stem, cerebellum, and spinal cord were stained with a mouse monoclonal antibodyd directed against a conserved epitope of the nonstructural (NS) 1 protein of MVEV, using methods described elsewhere.2 Granular and diffuse antigen staining was detected in a small number of degenerate neurons, neuronal processes, and the neuropil of spinal cord (Fig. 4). No antigen was detected in cerebrum, cerebellum, or brain stem. Most lesions did not contain anti- gen staining. Samples of blood, cerebrospinal fluid, brain, spinal cord, and facial nerve were tested by reverse transcription nested polymerase chain reaction assays (RT-nPCRs) for a range of arboviruses, including alphaviruses,21 flavi- viruses,14 and orbiviruses. The latter used an in-house, developmental method still undergoing validation in equids. For flaviviruses, primers FU1PM, cFD3PM, FU2, and cFD4PM of a published method14 were used. Primers FU2 and cFD4PM were modified to include redundancies and to enable reaction with a wider range of flaviviruses than the primers described in the original method. The primer sequences used were as follows: FU1PM (TACAACATGATGGGVAARAGWGARAA), cFD3PM (ARCATGTCTTCYGTBGTCATCCA), FU2 (modified) (GCTGATGACACMGCYGGMTGG GAYAC), and cFD4PM (modified) (AYNACRCARTCRTCYCCRCT). Figure 1. Five-year-old Australian stock horse; cerebral white matter. Dense perivascular cuff of lymphocytes and histiocytes. Hematoxylin and eosin. Bar = 50 µm. Figure 2. Five-year-old Australian stock horse; cervical spinal cord. Perivascular cuffing, diffuse and focal gliosis, and focal hemorrhage (arrow), largely confined to the gray matter. White matter (WM) is relatively unaffected. Hematoxylin and eosin. Bar = 500 µm. Figure 3. Five-year-old Australian stock horse; medulla oblongata. Satellitosis of a chromatolytic neuron with pyknotic nucleus (arrow); diffuse gliosis. Hematoxylin and eosin. Bar = 50 µm. Encephalitis caused by Murray Valley encephalitis virus 433 All samples were negative for alphaviruses and orbivi- ruses. Positive results for flavivirus were obtained from all samples. Brain and spinal cord samples yielded much brighter amplicon bands than samples of cerebrospinal fluid or nerve, and the reaction from the blood sample was very weak. The flavivirus-positive samples were further tested with an in-house, developmental RT-nPCR specific for Kunjin virus; all samples tested negative. Three samples of cerebrum, 1 sample of cervical spinal cord, and 1 sample of facial nerve were inoculated into yel- low fever mosquito Aedes aegypti (AA) C6/36 cells incu- bated at 28°C for 2 weeks. This was followed by subculture into BSR cells, a clone of baby hamster kidney (BHK)-21 cells, for 1 week at 34°C with supplementation of 5% CO 2 . The AA and BSR cell lines were maintained in a minimum essential medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serume and the following antimicrobials: penicillin (100 IU/ml), streptomycin (100 µg/ml), and amphotericin B (2 ng/ml). Virus was isolated from all samples except facial nerve. Cells showed cytopathic effect characterized by severe cytoplas- mic vacuolation, stringing, rounding-up, and detachment. Supernatants from positive cell culture samples tested PCR- positive for flavivirus. The RT-PCR amplicons (415 bp) were purifiedf and used to template dye termination DNA sequencing reactions using a dideoxynucleotide sequencing kitg and the nested flavivi- rus PCR primers (FU2 [modified] and cFD4PM [modified]). Amplicons were sequenced in both the sense and antisense directions. The reactions were resolved by the Griffith University DNA Sequencing Facility (Nathan, Queensland, Australia), and the resulting chromatograms were proofread and aligned using sequencing software.h The flavivirus group amplicon from virus isolated in cell culture was deter- mined to have an identical nucleotide sequence to those obtained directly from tissue specimens. The consensus nucleotide sequence has been recorded as GenBank acces- sion no. JN206679. This sequence was compared to those in GenBank using the search engine BLAST (http://www.ncbi. nlm.nih.gov/blast/Blast.cgi). The highest identity (96%) was with the NS5 gene of MVEV AF161266. BLAST in GenBank of the translated sequence resulted in a 98% similarity with the NS5 protein of MVEV AAC58777 and AAF05296. No other matches were indicated with the nucleotide search. Matches with lower identities (<90%) were noted with other flaviviruses such as Alfuy virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, Usuto virus, WNV, and Kunjin virus. Further RT-PCR testing of virus culture extract was per- formed as previously described11 to produce a 462-bp ampli- con of the envelope gene. The amplicon was sequenced (GenBank accession no. JN119766) and aligned with analo- gous gene regions of reference sequences using ClustalW, as implemented in MEGA 4.24 Subsequent phylogenetic analy- sis indicated that the equine MVEV isolate belongs to geno- type 1 (Fig. 5), with highest levels of nucleotide sequence identity to the Queensland strain 857-2002, isolated from Burketown in 2002.12 Close genetic relationships also were inferred with other Queensland and Western Australian strains isolated between 1989 and 2002 (98.3–99.6% nucleo- tide sequence identity). The results suggest that this strain might have been introduced into southeast Queensland from an endemic focus in either northern Queensland or north- western Australia. Outside of the endemic area, there is a strong association between outbreaks of Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) and certain weather patterns, including excessive rainfall in east- ern watersheds.20 Monto, in the north Burnett region of south- east Queensland, is not within the endemic area. Although higher-than-average rainfall was recorded in Monto during the summer months (January and February 2008) preced- ing this event, the factors responsible for the current equine case remain unknown. No human cases of MVE, and a single human case of Kunjin virus infection, were recorded from Queensland during 2008 (Australian Government, Department of Health and Ageing: 2005, National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System. Available at: http://www .health.gov.au/internet/main/Publishing.nsf/Content/ cda-surveil-nndss-nndssintro.htm. Accessed May, 25, 2011). The diagnosis of encephalomyelitis due to MVEV in the current case was based on a combination of consistent histo- pathology, demonstration of flavivirus antigen within neurons and neuropil, virus isolation, positive RT-PCR, and nucleotide sequencing. The nonsuppurative encephalomyeli- tis in the horse in the present study has the histological hall- marks of a viral infection of the central nervous system: neuronal degeneration, reactivity of the glia, and perivascular cuffing with lymphocytes and histiocytes.17 Although there Figure 4. Five-year-old Australian stock horse. Cervical spinal cord, showing viral antigen labeling of a degenerate neuronal cell body and process. Peroxidase immunohistochemistry using 4G4 antibody, counterstained with hematoxylin. Bar = 100 µm. 434 Gordon et al. are guidelines for differentiating some of the viral encepha- litides of horses based on morphology,3,4 there are no pub- lished descriptions of the neuropathology of MVEV infections in horses. Moderate to severe nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis and meningoencephalitis were reported in 2 horses that died in southern Australia in 1974 during an epidemic of human MVE,7 but infection with MVEV could not be confirmed in either horse. Horses with naturally occurring WNV infection have nonsuppurative polioenceph- alomyelitis, with the most severe lesions located in the Figure 5. Phylogenetic relationships of the equine isolate of Murray Valley encephalitis virus (MVEV; highlighted) with reference MVEV strains. The tree was constructed from a 462-nucleotide region of the envelope gene using the neighbor-joining method and the maximum composite likelihood model of evolution (MEGA software version 4.0). Japanese encephalitis virus is shown as the outgroup. Percentage bootstrap values from 1,000 replicates are indicated, with a cutoff value of 50%. The scale bar represents 0.05 nucleotide substitutions per site. Details of MVEV strains are shown as strain name/species of origin (H = human; M = mosquito; E = equine)/place and state of origin/year of isolation. GenBank accession numbers are bracketed, and genotype designation is indicated. NSW = New South Wales; PNG = Papua New Guinea; QLD = Queensland; VIC = Victoria; WA = Western Australia. Encephalitis caused by Murray Valley encephalitis virus 435 brainstem and spinal cord.4 In the current case of MVE, the most severe lesions were also located within the brainstem and spinal cord, but preferential involvement of gray matter was evident only in the latter. Other features common to the 2 infections include petechial and ring haemorrhages4 and a relative scarcity of flavivirus antigen detectable by immuno- histochemistry.3 In the current case, despite widespread dis- tribution of severe lesions, antigen was confined to 1 section of the spinal cord, and it was sparse within this location. This would indicate that the viral antigen was probably largely cleared or blocked by local central nervous system antibody at the time of death. The differential diagnosis of viral encephalitides in Australian horses has, until recently, been a short list. Many of the recognized viral equine encephalitides are exotic to Australia; such encephalitides include the alphaviruses Eastern equine encephalitis virus, Western equine encepha- litis virus, and Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus; Rabies virus; Equine encephalosis virus; Borna disease virus; and other tick-borne encephalitides such as Louping ill virus.8 For Australian horses, there are infrequent records of enceph- alomyelitis attributable to Equid herpesvirus 1,23 Hendra virus,6 and Kunjin virus.1 Japanese encephalitis virus has caused subclinical infections in horses in Torres Strait (north of the Australian mainland),10 is spreading into previously nonendemic areas,5 and should be considered in future out- breaks of equine neurological disease. At the time the horse in the current case was diagnosed with encephalitis, Hendra virus infection was considered to be a cause of predominantly fulminating respiratory disease in horses.19 In June 2008, the 10th recognized outbreak of Hendra virus infection manifested primarily as neurological disease.6 The serious zoonotic risk of Hendra virus infection now dictates a much more cautious approach to postmortem sampling in horses with neurological disease (Queensland Government: 2011, Guidelines for veterinarians handling potential Hendra virus infection in horses, version 4.1. Available at: http://www.dpi.qld.gov.au/4790_13371.htm. Accessed May 26, 2011). This zoonotic risk complicates the future diagnosis of flaviviral, and indeed any infectious encephalomyelitis, in Queensland horses. There is height- ened awareness of the potential for flaviviruses to spread, emerge, and appear in new geographic locations,15 and the current confirmed equine case of MVE could likely be the forerunner of further such cases.
