F or p er so na l u se o nl y. http://online.liebertpub.com/action/showImage?doi=10.1089/vbz.2006.0634&iName=master.img-002.jpg&w=360&h=178 http://online.liebertpub.com/action/showImage?doi=10.1089/vbz.2006.0634&iName=master.img-003.jpg&w=227&h=188 margiantus, and D. reticulatus have been identi- fied as being distributed in Korea (Lee 1999). We detected TBEV genes in three pools of H. longicornis and in one pool of I. nipponensis. These two species have not been recorded pre- viously as vectors for TBEV. However, they are the dominant species in Korea, and several hu- man tick bite cases involving both species have been reported there (Chung et al. 2006, Noh 1983, Lee et al. 1997). H. longicornis is impor- tant medically because it is a predominant species in human and veterinary medicine in Korea, Japan, and China (Hoogstraal et al. 1968, Kim et al. 2005a). The positive ratio of E gene of TBEV in tick and rodent samples was 0.6% and 16.6%, respectively. In our in vivo analy- sis, only mice inoculated with some of the ro- dent samples showed neurological symptoms. We do not know whether the virus titer of TBEV in the ticks was too low to cause clinical signs in mice. Most TBEVs use rodents as main- tenance and amplifying hosts, and probably as reservoir hosts, mainly in the genera Apodemus and Clethrionomys (Perkins et al. 2003, Suss 2003). The detection of TBEV in lung samples of a Korean dominant rodent, A. agrarius, sug- gests that TBEV may be maintained in other wild mammals in Korea (Chung et al. 2006). Our result showing 98% identity with the West- ern subtype differs from our prediction that the isolates would be of the Far Eastern subtype because TBEVs isolated in neighboring coun- tries such as Russia, Japan, and China are clas- sified into the Far Eastern subtype. This sug- gests that the existence of other subtypes of TBEV should be determined in domestic vec- tors and clinical samples in Korea. Our results are consistent with our previous studies in which we detected TBEVs in I. nipponensis, H. flava, and H. longicornis showing subtypes ge- netically related to the Western subtype (Kim et al. 2005b). Why TBE has not been reported in Korea may be explained by the natural en- vironmental conditions of forests in Korea, which differ from the TBEV-endemic areas in other parts of Asia and in Europe. In addition, Korea does not now have a private diagnostic laboratory with biosafety level 3 facilities to handle TBEV for providing an accurate diag- nosis (CDC, 1999). To our knowledge, this study is the first to isolate TBEV from wild ro- dents collected in Korea. Our data also suggest that the subtype distribution of TBEV is related to geography, and that species and biology of the tick vector may differ according to the ge- ographical area. In addition, it is necessary to confirm the existence of TBEV in other vectors and patients, and to compare their sequences with previous species isolated. Finally, a method for the accurate and prompt diagnosis of TBEV should be devel- oped to study the occurrence of TBE and to pre- pare a preventive plan to counter an outbreak. More research is needed to identify the infec- tion route of TBEV in nature because there are several reservoir hosts for the vector of TBEV. c:\jobs\journal\springer\virol\acp\09-11-01\708\vi708.dvi Arch Virol (2001) 146: 2341–2355 Phylogenetic analysis of the envelope gene of St. Louis encephalitis virus L. D. Kramer1,∗ and L. J. Chandler2 1Center for Vector-borne Disease Research, University of California, Davis, California, U.S.A. 2Center for Tropical Diseases, University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, Texas, U.S.A. Accepted July 9, 2001 Summary. The complete nucleotide sequences of the envelope gene of 62 geographic isolates of St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) virus were determined. Phy- logenetic analyses of the sequences, conducted using both maximum parsimony and neighbor-joining methods, included four other members of the Japanese encephalitis serogroup. The results indicated that the SLE isolates formed a monophyletic group in which isolates generally clustered according to geographic origin. Isolates from Panama and South America predominantly formed two large groupings, while isolates from the U.S. formed two other major groups. Several South and Central American strains were more closely related to strains isolated in the U.S., e.g., one isolate from Mexico and Panama, each, were closely related to two Tampa Bay, Florida, isolates, and an isolate from Brazil was closely re- lated to three isolates from Texas. The U.S. isolates also were not strictly grouped according to geographic source, e.g., some California isolates were closely re- lated to Texas or midwestern isolates, and a Florida isolate was closely related to three isolates from Maryland. The results of the phylogenetic analyses indicated that SLE virus is predominantly maintained locally, but has been transported occasionally between areas, both within and outside the U.S. Introduction St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) is a mosquito-borne viral disease of humans. The causative agent, SLE virus, is a member of the family Flaviviridae, in the genus ∗Current address: Arbovirus Research Laboratory, Wadsworth Center, New York State Department of Health, 5668 State Farm Rd, Slingerlands, NY 12159, U.S.A. 2342 L. D. Kramer and L. J. Chandler Flavivirus. The genome of the flaviviruses is single-stranded, positive-sense RNA, approximately 10,800 nucleotides long and composed of one open reading frame [7]. The structural proteins are located at the 5′ end of the genome; the non- structural genes, involved in viral replication, at the 3′ end of the genome in the order 5′-C-PrM-E-NS1-NS2A-NS2B-NS3-NS4A-NS4B-NS5-3′. SLE virus is a member of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) serocomplex, with other important human pathogens such as Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE), West Nile (WN) and JE viruses, and is the only member of this serocomplex that is enzootic in the United States (U.S.), with the probable exception of the recently introduced WN virus. SLE virus is widely distributed throughout theAmericas, having been isolated in Canada, U.S., Mexico [11], Central and South America and the Caribbean [1, 3, 12, 14, 15, 26]. In the U.S., SLE occurs in both endemic and epidemic forms, and cases occur annually [5]. A small number of human cases of SLE have been reported in Central and South America [14, 20, 32], but no large outbreaks in the region have been attributed to this virus [32]. SLE virus is maintained and amplified in the U.S. by horizontal transmission in a primary enzootic cycle involving wild birds, primarily passeriformes and columbiformes [37], and Culex mosquitoes [31, 38]. In the eastern states, two Culex pipiens complex mosquitoes, Cx. pipiens and Cx. quinquefasciatus, are the primary vectors [19]. In these areas, SLE virus occurs in both urban and suburban areas. In contrast, in the western U.S., SLE virus occurs more frequently in rural settings, especially in heavily irrigated areas where the primary vector, Culex tarsalis, breeds. A third distinct SLE cycle occurs in Florida, where Culex nigripalpus is the primary vector [19]. Less is known of the natural transmission cycle in Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America, where the virus has been isolated from Culex species, including Cx. tarsalis, Cx. pipiens, and Cx. nigripalpus [19, 34], as well as other genera, including Mansonia, Haemagogus and Sabethes. Birds are presumed to be the primary vertebrate host in the cycle, but conclusive studies have not been conducted. In South America, there are a number of isolates from mammals other than man, includingCalomysmusculinus, Mus musculis, Akodon sp, Didelphis marsupialis [22, 23], but it is not known whether these are dead-end or amplification hosts. Several studies of both urban and rural forms of SLE have shown recur- rence of transmission of the virus in a single geographic area, e.g., in Texas [18], and California [30] suggesting that virus is maintained locally from year to year, [25]. Phylogenetic analysis of isolates from the San Joaquin Valley of California over ≥34 years also indicated local persistence of virus [16], although the mechanism(s) by which the virus cycle is maintained during periods when active transmission is not detected is not known. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the maintenance of SLE virus over adverse seasons and years [29] including: 1) local maintenance in arthropod vectors either through vertical transmission or persistence in diapausing adults; 2) alternate arthropod vectors, such as mites, [18, 21, 28]; 3) reactivation of virus in chronically infected verte- brate hosts; 4) maintenance in alternate vertebrate hosts, such as bats [2]; and SLE virus phylogeny 2343 5) annual reintroduction of the virus from tropical and subtropical areas by migratory birds [25]. Epidemiological and experimental evidence has suggested the existence of strains of SLE virus with distinct biological differences [37]. Strains of the virus have been identified that differ in several phenotypic characteristics that may im- pact transmission and disease potential of the virus, including neurovirulence, ability to cause viremia in birds, and mosquito infectivity [4, 24, 35]. Limited genetic studies of selected strains, using oligonucleotide fingerprinting (ONF), demonstrated that viremia and neurovirulence correlated strongly with ONF pat- terns and with geographic origin of the virus strains [35]. Little is known of the specific viral molecular determinants that contribute to the epidemiology of SLE virus. Preliminary genetic analysis using ONF indicates that enzootic strains of the virus are distinct from strains isolated during epidemics [35]; however, phy- logenetic analyses of the envelope region of isolates from years of high and low activity in California and Texas revealed no consistent differences [16]. To further study the genetic variation of SLE virus and to clarify whether the virus is being transported between tropical and temperate America, the complete nucleotide sequence of the envelope gene was determined for 62 strains from different parts of the Americas. The envelope protein of the flaviviruses contains the major neutralizing epitopes, and is responsible for the important viral functions such as binding to cellular receptors, membrane fusion, virulence and tropism [26]. Because of the essential biological functions of the envelope protein, we chose to examine genetic variation of this portion of the genome. Phylogenetic analyses were performed to examine the genetic relatedness of the isolates, and to determine if the virus is maintained locally, or if movement of the virus has occurred across large geographic areas. Materials and methods Virus strains The SLE virus isolates used in this study were obtained from the University of Texas Med- ical Branch’s Arbovirus Reference Center, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Arbovirus Reference Center in Fort Collins, Colorado, the Texas Department of Health in Austin, the Harris County Public Health and Environmental Services Department in Houston, Texas, the Center for Vector-borne Disease Research, University of California, Davis, and the Viral and Rickettsial Disease Laboratory of the State Health Laboratory of California. A total of 62 strains from different geographic locations in the U.S., Mexico, Caribbean, and Central and South America were sequenced in this study. A list of the isolates, including their strain designation, source, passage history and geographic origin, along with the GenBank submission numbers, is presented in Table 1. An additional 18 strains from California which previously had been sequenced [16], were re-analyzed in a phylogenetic analysis with strains from Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas. RNA extraction Vero cells were infected with 0.1 PFU/cell SLE virus. When cytopathic effects were evident (4–7 days postinfection), RNA was extracted from the cells using TrizolTM (Gibco Life Sciences, MD) and resuspended in sterile dH2O. 2344 L. D. Kramer and L. J. Chandler SLE virus phylogeny 2345 2346 L. D. Kramer and L. J. Chandler Table 2. Primers for PCR amplification and sequencing of the SLE virus envelope gene Primer Genome position Sense Sequence 5′-3′ USE F880 880–901 pos CGATTGGATGGATGCTAGGTAG PCR; sequencing F1390 1390–1411 pos GTGCATGGTTCAACGGACTCTAC sequencing F1990 1990–2014 pos CTGCAAACCTCATGGATTTGACACC sequencing B1357 1357–1381 neg GCAACCTCATACTTGATGTTTTCTC RT; PCR; sequencing B1629 1608–1629 neg GGTTCAAGTCGTGAAACCAGTC sequencing B1991 1991–1972 neg AGTCACGGAGATGGGAACTC sequencing B1993 1993–1969 neg GCAGTCACGGAGATGGGAACTCGGC sequencing B2047 2047–2064 neg TCGCTCCCCCTGTGCTTA sequencing B2581 2581–2556 neg GGAGTCAGAGGGAAATACTTGTAGTC RT; PCR; sequencing B2586a 2586–2562 neg CAGTTGGAGTCAGAGGGAAATACTT RT; PCR; sequencing aUsed for amplification of South American, Central American and Caribbean isolates RT-PCR and nucleotide sequencing RT-PCR was carried out as previously described [8, 17]. The envelope gene extends from base 963 to 2465 on the SLE virus genome. The sequence of SLE strain MSI-7 (GenBank Accession No. M16614) [36] was scanned using the computer software program MacVector (International Biotechnologies, Inc., New Haven, CT), in order to design two primers desig- nated F880 and B2581 (B2586 for the Central and South American isolates) to amplify the entire E gene of the virus. A single product, approximately 1700 base pairs in size, was obtained using these primers. Seven internal primers were designed for direct sequencing of the PCR product. The sequence and location of all the primers on the genome are presented in Table 2. PCR products were purified using QIATM PCR purification kits (Qiagen, Inc., Chatsworth, CA). DNA was directly sequenced using the DyeDeoxy Terminator cycle sequence kits (Ap- plied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) at the UTMB Molecular Imaging and Sequencing Core Facility and the UC Davis Plant Genetics Facility. Sequences were edited using the Se- quencher program (Gene Codes Corporation, Ann Arbor, MI). After editing, the sequences were all trimmed to 1617 bp in length, representing bases 924–2540 on the genome. This included the entire envelope gene, with an additional 39 bases 5′ to the envelope and 75 bases 3′ to the envelope. Sequences were aligned using the Wisconsin Sequence Analysis Package (Genetics Computer Group, Inc., Madison, WI). Phylogenetic analysis The sequences of four related flaviviruses, JE (Accession # M55506) [27]; WN (M12294) [6]; Kunjin (D00246) [9], and MVE (X03467) [10] were obtained from GenBank and used as outgroups in the phylogenetic analysis. For phylogenetic analyses, the PAUP version 4b [33] and PHYLIP version 3.5c package [13] software programs were used. Bootstrapping was performed using 1000 replicates in both parsimony and distance analyses. For parsimony analysis, the heuristic search option, with random addition of sequences, was used. The PHYLIP package was used for distance analysis, using the neighbor-joining and parsimony algorithms. A distance matrix was prepared to determine the nucleotide sequence divergence among the strains. SLE virus phylogeny 2347 Nucleotide sequence accession numbers The nucleotide sequences of all of the virus isolates examined in this study were submitted to GenBank. The accession numbers are listed in Table 1. Results Phylogenetic analysis of the entire envelope gene The first set of analyses included the sequence of 1617 nucleotides encompassing the entire envelope gene (bases 963 to 2465 on the genome), and determined phylogenetic relationships among 62 strains of SLE virus and four related flavi- viruses, JE, MVE, Kunjin and West Nile viruses, which were included as out- group viruses. Phylogenetic analyses were performed using both parsimony and distance-based (neighbor-joining) methods. A distance matrix was prepared to examine the genetic distance between isolates. There was a minimum of 21% and a maximum of 30% nucleotide differ- ence between the SLE strains and the four outgroup viruses. Among SLE strains alone, there was a maximum of 10% [161] nucleotide differences. The two iso- lates from Argentina, CorAn9124 and CorAn9275 from 1966 and 1967, were the most distantly related; these strains had 161 and 160 nucleotide differences, respectively, from other SLE isolates. Using the PAUP program, 80 equally parsi- monious trees were generated, all with strong bootstrap values. These trees were robust and similar in topology, differing only in the relationships between six strains (SPAn9398, GHA3, PanAn902602 and three of the older Texas isolates). The neighbor-joining tree was similar to the 80 trees generated in PAUP. One of the 80 trees generated in PAUP is presented in Fig. 1. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the SLE strains from tropical and temper- ate America formed a monophyletic group (Fig. 1). The isolates were predomi- nantly, but not strictly, grouped according to geographic origin. In the parsimony analysis (Fig. 1), there are seven lineages, designated I–VII. Lineage I is com- prised of isolates from the Western U.S. and is subdivided into 2 major clusters, IA and IB. Cluster IA contains isolates from Kern County, California, made from 1953 to 1970; cluster IB consists of strains isolated from 1966 to 1998 from var- ious parts of the western U.S., including New Mexico, Colorado and California, as well as Texas. The most recent isolate from the Coachella Valley in southern California in 1998 is very closely related to the 1987 and 1989 Texas isolates from El Paso and Dallas, respectively. Other northern Texas isolates from 1966 from Dallas and 1968 from Hale County are closely related to other western U.S. isolates, i.e., one from New Mexico and one from Colorado in 1972. Lineage II contains the largest number of isolates and is formed by six major clusters of strains. Group IIA predominantly contains isolates made from 1955 to 1969 from North America, including central and south Florida from a raccoon andCx. nigripalpus, respectively, the south/central U.S. (Kentucky) from a flicker, and southern Texas (Rio Grande Valley) from man. Three Texas isolates with unknown histories are also included in this cluster, as well as a single isolate from Brazil, SPAn9398, isolated in 1968 from Akodon sp. A sister cluster, IIB, Fig. 1. Phylogenetic relationships among geographic strains of SLE virus based on the max- imum parsimony algorithm using PAUP 4b. This is one of 80 most parsimonious trees found. Bootstrap analysis was performed using 1000 replicates. The branch lengths indicate the amount of genetic divergence, with the scale bar representing approximately 10% diver- gence. The numbers on the branches are the bootstrap values. JE, WN, MVE and KUN viruses were used as outgroup strains in this analysis L. D. Kramer and L. J. Chandler: SLE virus phylogeny 2349 contains virus isolated from 1962 to 1998, including a human isolate from Florida (Tampa Bay), 3 strains from southern Texas (Houston and Corpus Christi) from Cx. pipiens, and one isolate from Cx. pipiens from Tennessee. Lineage IIC con- tains isolates from a variety of geographic locations in the U.S., i.e., the west – California, south central U.S. – Tennessee, Mississippi, the east – Maryland, and Florida, made from 1975 to 1992. A sister cluster, IID, contains strains isolated in Florida (Tampa Bay) which are closely related to isolates from Mexico and Panama several years later. The one isolate from Panama contained in lineage IID is from 1973 from a cormorant, PanAn 902604, and the one from Mexico was isolated in 1965 from a common egret [11]. A fifth group designated IIE consists of the Hubbard and Parton isolates from St. Louis, MO, from 1933 and 1937, and the sixth group, IIF, contains one isolate, GMO94, from Guatemala, from Culex nigripalpus, in 1969. Lineage III consists of a single isolate from Argentina, 79V2533, isolated in 1979 from Culex sppmosquitoes. Lineage IV contains five isolates from Panama from several mosquito genera includingHaemagogus andMansonia, made during the years 1973–1977. Lineage V consists of South American strains and one from Trinidad, and can be subdivided into VA and VB. Group VA contains isolates from Brazil and Argentina, Peru and Trinidad. Group VB contains 3 isolates from Brazil from 1960 to 1972, made from mosquito, opossum, and man. Lineage VI is a single isolate from Panama from 1983 from a sentinel chicken; and lineage VII contains two Argentinian isolates from 1966 and 1967 from rodents,Calomys musculinus andMus musculus. These strains are the most distantly related of the SLE strains analyzed, with 10% nucleotide difference. The clustering of isolates in the neighbor-joining tree (tree not shown) is nearly the same as in the parsimony tree, with the exception of the 1983 Panama isolate from the sentinel chicken which is loosely connected with the other Panamanian isolates in the neighbor-joining tree, but is in a separate lineage by itself in the parsimony tree. Phylogenetic analysis of a 277 base portion of the envelope gene of western U.S. isolates To examine more thoroughly the genetic relationships among the SLE strains from the western half of the U.S. and Texas, a second phylogenetic analysis was con- ducted. The nucleotide sequences of 18 isolates from California which had been previously determined [16] were included in an analysis with the 30 isolates from the western U.S. sequenced in this study. A 277-base pair portion of the envelope gene, corresponding to genome position 1263–1540 was analyzed. In the previous study [16], this region showed sufficient variability to discriminate between geno- types of the virus. The Fort Washington 4 strain from the eastern U.S., was used as the outgroup. The Parton isolate (Missouri, 1933) and the Mississippi 1975 isolate were also included. Parsimony and neighbor joining analyses were both done. Parsimony search generated 500 equally parsimonious trees. Neighbor joining demonstrated four major groupings of isolates from the western U.S. and Texas Fig. 2. Phylogenetic relationships among 48 strains of SLE virus isolated in the western U.S., based on neighbor-joining algorithm using the PHYLIP package. In this analysis, a 277 base portion of the E gene was used. The Fort Washington 4 strain from the eastern U.S. was used as an outgroup in this analysis. The tree is a consensus tree of 1000 bootstrap replicates. The numbers at the forks indicate the number of times the group consisting of the strains which are to the right of that fork occurred among the trees L. D. Kramer and L. J. Chandler: SLE virus phylogeny 2351 (Fig. 2). Group I consists of recent isolates from the Coachella, Imperial and San Joaquin Valleys of California, isolated from 1988 to 1992. Group IIA includes isolates from northern and southern California including the Sacramento Valley, San Joaquin Valley, the Imperial Valley and Los Angeles, as well as isolates from Colorado, New Mexico, and northwest Texas, i.e., Dallas, Hale County and El Paso. The isolates from California were made from 1969 to 1998, and from Texas from 1966 to 1989. Group IIB contains isolates predominantly from the San Joaquin Valley from 1952 to 1986, as well as one isolate from Los Angeles, 1984, one from the Imperial Valley, 1978, and one from the Sacramento Valley, 1972. Group III was comprised of isolates from southern Texas from 1983 to 1998, i.e., Houston and Corpus Christi, and the 1933 Parton isolate from St. Louis. Group IV contains two isolates from Texas with unknown histories and the 1955 Rio Grande isolate. One San Joaquin (1989), Sacramento (1972), and Coachella (1989) Valley isolate from California do not fit in a lineage with other isolates, but are related to the 1975 Mississippi isolate. Discussion The results of the phylogenetic studies indicate that in the Americas, geographic groupings of SLE virus strains predominate, but there are exceptions. Bootstrap values for most of the major groupings in both phylogenetic analyses were strong. California and Texas isolates both fall into two separate lineages, I and II, in the analysis of the entire envelope gene. Texas isolates from the northwestern portion of the state, i.e., the high plains region, are more closely related to isolates from western U.S., including Colorado, New Mexico, and California. Isolates from the southeastern portion of Texas are more closely related to isolates from the central U.S. (Kentucky and Tennessee). In 1975, during a large outbreak, SLE virus moved throughout the U.S., as indicated by the genetic relatedness of isolates from Tennessee, Mississippi, and California. Movement of virus within the U.S. is also evident from the close relatedness of the 1998 isolate from the Coachella Valley, CA, and the 1987 and 1989 isolates from Texas. Florida isolates also varied in genotype, although all isolates were located in lineage II. One isolate from 1979 from an unknown location within Florida was very closely related to 3 isolates from Maryland from 1975–1977, including one winter isolate from Cx. pipiens (Fort Washington 4); and two isolates from the Gulf coast of Florida, from Tampa Bay in 1962, were very closely related to a Mexican isolate from 1965, and less closely related to a 1973 isolate from Panama from a cormorant. These results indicate that some movement of SLE virus occurs around the U.S. The similarity of the Florida isolate to the Maryland isolates indicates that virus may have been introduced into Florida from Maryland or other parts of the South, or vice versa, at one time. These results are particularly significant in view of the introduction of WNV into the U.S., and its establishment in the northeast. The movement of SLE virus portends the potential of WNV to spread to other areas in the U.S. 2352 SLE virus phylogeny One of the hypotheses for endemic persistence of SLE in the U.S. is that virus is reintroduced annually from areas in Central or South America. The results of this phylogenetic analysis indicate that reintroduction does not occur often, or if it does, that virus is reintroduced from exactly the same site each year. Viral movement also may proceed from north to south. When the fall bird migration takes place, SLE is at its peak activity in Florida. Indeed, the Tampa Bay isolates were made prior to the Mexican and Panamanian isolates indicating virus may have been carried south by migratory birds during the fall migration. The predominant geographic separation of SLE strains and genetic homo- geneity over time support the hypothesis of local transmission and maintenance of the virus. Mechanisms of viral overwintering have been explored in detail by Reeves [29], the most likely for SLE including persistence in chronically infected birds and/or winter survival in diapausing adultCulexmosquitoes. These possible mechanisms are currently under study. In Texas, both urban and rural cycles of SLE transmission exist. In Houston, the virus circulates in an urban cycle and is transmitted by Cx. quinquefasciatus, while in western Texas, the virus is transmitted by Cx. tarsalis in a rural cycle. The results of our study indicate that the north Texas isolates are closely related to the endemic/enzootic California isolates, while the isolates from the coastal regions (Corpus Christi and Houston) are closely related. This close relationship among the California and rural Texas strains is not surprising and supports the hypothesis that when cases occur in urban areas in north Texas (for example, in Dallas) that virus has been introduced from the endemic cycle [18]. Future studies should include examining isolates obtained from Dallas over a period of time to determine if they are being reintroduced from the rural (Culex tarsalis-borne) cycle or if they are maintained in an urban form (Cx. quinquefasciatus-borne) similar to what occurs in Houston. The phylogenetic analysis demonstrating multiple lineages generally grouped by geographic location is similar to results obtained in other studies of SLE virus [35]. In those studies, oligonucleotide fingerprinting of viral RNA demonstrated six groupings of the virus from different geographic locations. The genetic differ- ences between virus strains that circulate in urban and rural cycles are not known. To understand completely the epidemiology and virulence of SLE, genetic infor- mation such as evolutionary rates, genetic basis of virulence, and identification of genetic markers, will be necessary. There generally were no clear differences be- tween isolates made from different host sources, such as man, rodents, birds and mosquitoes. One exception is the Panamanian mosquito isolates which grouped together while the cormorant isolate from the same time period was more similar to the North American isolates in lineage II. In the parsimony tree, the sen- tinel chicken isolate from Panama was in a separate lineage by itself, but in the neighbor-joining tree, it was related to the other Panamanian isolates, but less closely than the others were related to each other. One Florida isolate from man, TBH28 was very closely related to a second Florida isolate from the same year from Cx. nigripalpus, while a third human isolate from Florida, GHA 3, is in a separate cluster within the same lineage. The Brazilian isolate from Akodon sp is SLE virus phylogeny 2353 also in this lineage, but the other six Brazilian isolates from various sources are grouped together in lineage V. Serological Evidence of USUTU Virus Occurrence in North-Eastern Italy ORIGINAL ARTICLE Serological Evidence of USUTU Virus Occurrence in North-Eastern Italy R. Lelli1, G. Savini1, L. Teodori1, G. Filipponi1, A. Di Gennaro1, A. Leone1, L. Di Gialleonardo1, L. Venturi2 and V. Caporale1 1 Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale dell’Abruzzo e Molise ‘G. Caporale’, Via Campo Boario, Teramo, Italy 2 Azienda Unità Sanitaria Locale di Ravenna, Ravenna, Italy Impacts • The paper evidenced the circulation of USUTU virus (USUV) in Italy. • USUTU virus is a vector-borne virus not present in Italy which, like West Nile and Chikungunya viruses, uses mosquitoes and birds to complete its life cycle. • Events, such as the one just described, are indicators of possible emerging threats in Europe owing to vector-borne agents. Introduction The USUTU virus (USUV) is an arthropod-borne virus belonging to the family of Flaviviridae, genus Flavivirus. Its name has been derived from a river located in Swazi- land, the place where it was first isolated. It is included in the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) group (Heinz et al., 2000) and it is closely related to human pathogens, such as JEV, Murray Valley encephalitis virus (MVEV), Saint Louis encephalitis virus (SLEV) and West Nile virus (WNV) (Kuno et al., 1998; Bakonyi et al., 2004). As the other members of the group, its natural cycle involves birds and mosquitoes. Up to 2001, the virus was never associated with severe or fatal diseases in animals or humans and never reported outside tropical and subtro- pical Africa. In 2001, USUV was first described in wild birds in and around Vienna, Austria (Weissenböck et al., 2002) and since then, the infection has been causing deaths in the blackbird population of the Country (Mei- ster et al., 2007). Encephalitis, myocardial degeneration and necrosis in the liver and spleen were the lesions observed in infected birds (Chvala et al., 2004). Italy is adjacent to Austria, and because of its peculiar geographic location, is subjected to the incursions of new or re-emer- gent pathogens, especially those transmitted by vectors as evidenced by recent Bluetongue and West Nile outbreaks. As part of a systematic surveillance programme to moni- tor possible entrance and/or circulation of vector-borne viruses (West Nile and other flaviviruses), since 2001, sentinel-chicken flocks were placed throughout the Italian territory nearby areas considered at risk of virus introduc- tion. They have been periodically checked for the pres- ence of antibodies against flaviviruses in general and WNV in particular. In these areas, the wild bird mortality and the WNV seroprevalence in horses were also moni- tored (Filipponi et al., 2005). Keywords: Chicken; horse; plaque reduction neutralization test; USUTU virus; West Nile virus Correspondence: Giovanni Savini. Tel.: +390861 332440; Fax: +390861 332251; E-mail: g.savini@izs.it Received for publication April 8, 2008 doi: 10.1111/j.1863-2378.2008.01146.x Summary In the recent years, USUTU virus (USUV), a flavivirus of the Japanese enceph- alitis virus complex, has been reported in Central Europe. As part of a system- atic surveillance programme to monitor possible entrance and/or circulation of vector-borne viruses, since 2001, sentinel-chicken flocks were placed through- out the Italian territory nearby areas considered at risk of virus introduction. They have been periodically checked for the presence of antibodies against fla- viviruses by indirect ELISA, plaque reduction neutralization test for USUTU, West Nile and tick-borne encephalitis viruses. In July 2007, a sentinel chicken in a flock of 20 animals located within the Ravenna province seroconverted to USUV reaching neutralizing titres up to 1 : 5120. A second chicken serocon- verted to the same virus 2 months later. Although no virus was rescued from these animals and from wild or farm birds sampled in the area, these results still provided evidence of the circulation of USUV in north-eastern Italy. Zoonoses and Public Health ª 2008 The Authors Journal compilation ª 2008 Blackwell Verlag • Zoonoses Public Health. 55 (2008) 361–367 361 The presence of low neutralizing antibody titres to USUV were detected in wild birds and sentinel chickens in England and North Eastern Italy (Buckley et al., 2003; Rizzoli et al., 2007). The diagnostic and epidemiological value of these results is however difficult to interpret, as in these studies, the plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT) cut-off titres were based on a 50% reduction in plaque counts (PRNT50). This paper documents the occurrence of USUV in north-eastern Italy by using the PRNT90, the test officially recommended by the World Organisation of animal health [Office International des Épizooties (OIE), 2006]. Materials and Methods Virus strains The strains used in this study were the USUV strain Vienna 2001-blackbird (939/01) and Tick-borne encepha- litis virus (TBEV) Hypr strain, which were kindly provided by Prof Zdenek Hubalek (Medical Zoology Laboratory, Institute of Vertebrate Biology, Academy of Sciences, Valtice, Czech Republic), the West Nile strain Eg-101 kindly supplied by the Unité des arbovirus et des Fièvres hémorragiques, Institut Pasteur, Paris. Production of antisera Sera against TBEV, USUV and WNV were produced by injecting guinea pigs with the reference viruses. In brief, 1 ml of AlPO4 was added to 20 ml of a suspension of the reference virus against which the serum should be pro- duced. The new viral suspension was centrifuged at 2000 rpm for 5 min at 4�C. The supernatant was discarded and the pellet re-suspended in 20 ml of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Two millilitres of the suspension was then intraperitoneally inoculated into each of the two guinea pigs. The injections were repeated once a week for 3 weeks. Ten days after the last inoculum, the animals were bled and the samples were tested for the presence of neutralizing antibodies. If the level of antibod- ies was not adequate, two further weekly injections were administered. When obtained an adequate titre, the guinea pigs were exanguinated and the serum collected. Animals Chickens. A sentinel flock of 20 domestic chickens (Gallus domesticus) was included in this study. It was one of the sentinel flocks located in at-risk areas throughout the Ital- ian territory to monitor WNV circulation and vector- borne viruses. The flock was in the province of Ravenna (Fig. 1). The animals were bled every month from May to September. A total of 100 serum samples were collected during the entire period (Table 1). Following seroconver- sion, the chickens were euthanized, and from each animal, cloacal swabs, in addition to brain, spleen, heart and kidney were collected. Wild birds. From a swampy area located in the Ravenna province in close proximity to the sentinel flock, samples were collected from 83 birds belonging to 21 species (Table 2). Eighty-two serum samples and 28 cloacal swabs were taken and tested for serological and virological evi- dence of USUV. Two carcasses of a Rufous Nightingale and a Garden Warbler were also examined for the presence of USUV and other flaviviruses. Horses. Serum and EDTA blood samples were also col- lected from a total of 69 horses belonging to five stables located close by the sentinel flock within Ferrara and Ravenna provinces. Serological investigation. To detect the presence of USUV- and WNV-specific antibody response, serum samples were tested by ELISA, PRNT (OIE, 2006) and virus neutraliza- tion test in microtitre plates (SN). However, owing to their small quantity, for some sera, it was decided to use Fig. 1. Locations of USUTU virus seroconversion in Italy and birds migrating routes from Northern Europe to Africa. USUTU Virus Occurrence in North-Eastern Italy ª 2008 The Authors Journal compilation ª 2008 Blackwell Verlag • Zoonoses Public Health. 55 (2008) 361–367 363 the PRNT or virus neutralization test in microtitre plates only. To rule out possible cross-reactions of the tests, positive samples (titre ‡1 : 20) were also tested for TBEV antibodies by PRNT. Indirect ELISA. The ELISA used was an IgG ELISA set up according to Tsai et al. (1998). Plates were coated with WNV antigen prepared on Vero E6 cells according to the method used by the Unité des arbovirus et des Fièvres hémorragiques, Institut Pasteur, Paris (Tsai et al., 1998) and IgG antibodies were revealed by peroxidase antibody (Sigma, Munich, Germany). The positive threshold was selected by adding three standard deviations to the optical density mean of negative controls. The indirect ELISA was chosen to screen the samples in order to take advan- tage of its ability to detect antibodies against a wide range of flaviviruses. Virus neutralization test in microtitre plates (SN) and PRNT. Prior to the SN test, the USUV and WNV anti- gens were titrated in a cytopathic effect (CPE) TCID50 assay using African green monkey kidney Vero cells (ATCC CRL-1586 VERO C1008). Serial 10-fold dilutions of the antigen were made. After 6 days, the titre was determined by using the Reed and Muench formula. The serum samples were inactivated at 56�C for 30 min. Start- ing from 1 : 5, serial 2-fold dilutions were made from serum samples in microtitre plates, and 100 TCID units of antigen were added to each dilution. Thereafter, the mixtures were incubated at 37�C for 1 h and 105 vero cells were added to the wells. Plates were read after 6 days of incubation at 37�C. The antibody titre was defined as the reciprocal of the highest dilution of the test serum sample, which showed at least 90% neutralization. Posi- tive and negative control sera were included in each plate. The PRNT procedure to detect WNV antibodies was performed as described by the OIE Manual of standards (World Organisation for Animal Health (Office Interna- tional des Épizooties: OIE), 2006). This method was also adapted for detecting USUV and TBEV antibodies in this study. The PRNT titre was determined as the highest serum dilution with a 90% reduction of the number of plaques (PRNT90). Sera with a titre of at least 1 : 20 were consid- ered positive. The specificity of this assay for antibodies to the viruses tested (i.e. USUV and WNV) had been validated by using WNV-, TBEV- and USUV-positive test sera. Virological investigation. To detect Flavivirus and WNV antigen directly from avian organs, cloacal swabs (Chvala et al., 2005), serum or EDTA blood samples, nested and real-time (RT)-PCR were used, whereas the infection of C6/36 confluent monolayer followed by two passages in Vero E6 cell cultures were used for virus isolation (Bernard et al., 2001). Nested RT-PCR and RT-PCR. The nested RT-PCR described by Sànchez-Seco et al. (2005) was used for detecting Flavivirus antigen, whereas the RT-PCR described by Lanciotti et al. (2000) was the method used to evidence WNV RNA. The sensitivity of the methods were increased by using High Pure Viral Nucleic Acid Kit (Roche, Nutley, NJ, USA) in the viral RNA extraction phase and adding an internal control to the reaction in order to reduce the numbers of false-negative results. Virus isolation. Virus isolation was performed on C6/36 and Vero E6 cell monolayers by using the 24 flat- bottomed well microplate. C6/36 monolayers (90–100% confluent) were infected with 100- to 200-ll homogenate samples. Homogenate samples were allowed to adsorb for 1 h at 28�C with gentle swirling every 15 min. Leibovitz medium with 2% foetal calf serum, 100 U/ml penicillin, 200 lg/ml streptomycin and 12.5 U/mL nystatin was then added to the infected cells. The plates were incubated at 28�C . After 7 days, cells were scraped and centrifuged. Hundred to 200 microlitres of supernatant were then used to infect Vero cell monolayers (90–100% confluent). Samples were allowed to adsorb for 1 h at 37�C with gen- tle swirling every 15 min. Eagle’s minimal essential med- ium with 2% foetal calf serum, 100 U/ml penicillin, 200 lg/ml streptomycin and 12.5 U/ml nystatin was then added to the infected cells. Plates were incubated at 37�C. Cells were monitored daily for 7 days for CPE. Cells showing CPE demonstrated rounding up in the early stage of infection and many floating single cells later in the infection. Infected cells that showed CPE were evalu- ated by RT-PCR, and a sample (100 ll) of the superna- tant was passed on another Vero cell monolayer to confirm WNV. Infected cells that showed CPE were also evaluated by immunofluorescence assay (IFA) using the ascitic fluid from WNV and anti-IgG fluorescein-5-iso- thiocyanate conjugated and by electron microscopy. Cells from monolayers that did not show CPE were passaged onto fresh Vero cell monolayers and monitored for another 7 days. Cells that did not show CPE after 14 days were also tested as previously described. Only cell cultures that did not stain with IFA, negative to RT-PCR or elec- tron microscopy, were reported negative. Results Sentinel chickens The results of the serological and virological investigations carried on sentinel-chicken samples are shown in Table 2. USUTU Virus Occurrence in North-Eastern Italy R. Lelli et al. ª 2008 The Authors 364 Journal compilation ª 2008 Blackwell Verlag • Zoonoses Public Health. 55 (2008) 361–367 Two animals seroconverted for USUV, one in July and the other in September. The neutralizing titres were up to 1 : 5120 in the first animal and 1 : 20 in the second. In the first animal, antibody titres to WNV were also found. RT- PCR and virus isolation performed on organs, swabs and EDTA blood failed to detect or isolate infectious viruses. Other species All samples collected from different species of wild birds showed evidence neither of USUV nor of other flaviviruses. Of the 69 horses tested, nine were positive to ELISA, four of them had neutralizing titres for USUV. The titres ranged from 1 : 20 to 1 : 40. No TBEV- or WNV-neutralizing antibodies were observed in the horse-positive sera. Discussion Since 2001, USUV has found a new habitat in central Eur- ope completing its life cycle in local species of birds and mosquitoes successfully (Weissenböck et al., 2002; Stein- metz et al., 2007). Unexpectedly, following the first report, only on two occasions, the virus spread beyond the Aus- trian borders causing mortality in wild and captive Passer- iformes and Strigiformes around Zurich Zoo, Switzerland (Steinmetz et al., 2007) and in black birds in Hungary (Bakonyi et al., 2007). Apart from these episodes, the virus was not reported elsewhere in Europe (Weissenböck et al., 2003). The modest spread was attributed to the bird spe- cies involved in the transmission cycle, which are quite sedentary with little tendency to fly great distances during the season of virus activity (Weissenböck et al., 2003). Presence of low neutralizing antibody titres to USUV was detected in wild birds and sentinel chickens in England and North Eastern Italy (Buckley et al., 2003; Rizzoli et al., 2007). In these studies, the PRNT cut-off titres were based on a 50% reduction in plaque counts (PRNT50), whereas for diagnostic and epidemiological purposes, the more stringent PRNT90 titres were strongly recommended in order to avoid aspecific reactions and the frequent back- ground serum cross-reactivities occurring among flavivi- ruses (WHO, 2007). The present study documents the circulation of USUV in north-eastern Italy. The evidence was based on the seroconversion observed in sentinel chickens by indirect ELISA, PRNT90 and SN. The PRNTs are the methods recommended by the OIE manual of diagnostic test for terrestrial animals (World Organisation for Animal Health (Office International des Épizooties: OIE), 2006). All the methods used in this study evidenced several WNV reactors owing to cross-reactivity with USUV. This phenomenon, which has already been described (Bakonyi et al., 2005; Meister et al., 2007), was minimal and only occurred in sera with high USUV titres. These sera showed, in fact, a low neutralizing activity also against WNV, but the titres were at least four logs less than those of USUV. While earlier European outbreaks involved deaths of captive and wild birds (Weissenböck et al., 2002; Bakonyi et al., 2007; Steinmetz et al., 2007), no fatalities were reported related to the episode described in this study. Evidence of the virus occurrence was shown only in sentinel chickens. Despite seroconversion, chickens remained healthy, and no pathological findings were observed. Low pathogenicity associated with USUV and related viruses, such as WNV, MVEV and SLE has already been reported in chickens. It was also shown that these animals, when infected with WNV, MVEV and SLEV, developed reliable and robust seroconversions (Maguire and Miles, 1965; Campbell and Hore, 1975; Calisher et al., 1986; Reisen et al., 1994; Komar et al., 2001), which make chickens eligible for vector competence studies and virus activity monitoring programmes (Morris et al., 1994; Ko- mar, 2001; Broom et al., 2002a, 2002b; Blackmore et al., 2003; Quirin et al., 2004; Reisen et al., 2004). In this epi- sode, USUV natural infection was able to elicit high and persistent neutralizing titres in a sentinel chicken, indicat- ing that this species might be an effective sentinel animal for USUV and/or flavivirus surveillance programmes. These findings are in disagreement with the observation that, following USUV experimental infection in chickens, viraemia and seroconversion were inconsistent (Chvala et al., 2005). This discrepancy could be attributed to a dif- ferent strain involved or, alternatively, to the fact that nat- ural infection could be more efficient in generating an immune response than an experimental one. Unfortu- nately, no virus was isolated either from infected chickens or from the other species examined. The period of sero- conversion (June–July) together with the absolute absence of bird fatalities might suggest that USUV could have been entered in Italy through migrating birds. The latters have been implicated in spreading flaviviruses in Europe, Asia, Africa and the Middle East during migrations (Ernek et al., 1977; Rappole et al., 2000; Malkinson and Banet, 2002; Malkinson et al., 2002) and play a major role in introducing these viruses into new regions (Rappole et al., 2000; Autorino et al., 2002). In their annual migrating route from and to Africa, where most arthropod-borne viruses co-circulate and are actively transmitted between birds and mosquitoes, many birds rest in swampy areas in Italy, such as the one in the vicinity of the area, where the reported seroconversion occurred. However, to support this hypothesis, the virus should have been isolated and sequenced. Unfortunately, no virus evidence has been found in the migratory bird specimens tested up to now. These negative results are not entirely surprising consider- ing the brief period in which viraemia persists in infected birds (Komar et al., 2003). R. Lelli et al. USUTU Virus Occurrence in North-Eastern Italy ª 2008 The Authors Journal compilation ª 2008 Blackwell Verlag • Zoonoses Public Health. 55 (2008) 361–367 365 Two months after the first chicken seroconversion, a second sentinel animal showed neutralizing antibodies to USUV. In consideration of the low titre, they could have been a consequence of a cross-reaction owing to infection of other flaviviruses; however, the fact that the serum was negative to TBEV and WNV antibodies and that the chicken was in the same flock in which an USUTU seroconversion occurred, could support the USUTU sero- conversion hypothesis. It could be the result of virus transmission among non-migratory local birds via indi- genous mosquitoes. Transmission of mosquito-borne flaviviruses, in fact, occurs mainly from viraemic birds to mosquitoes which after completion of the extrinsic incu- bation period are capable of transmitting the virus to a new avian host. Similarly, the presence of neutralizing antibodies in horses kept in proximity of the positive chicken flock could also be a consequence of the indige- nous mosquito infection or, alternatively, a consequence of other flavivirus infection. The pathogenicity of USUV for mammals and for man is still unclear. Contrary to some WNV strains which are able to cause diseases in birds, humans, several mammal species and reptiles (McLean et al., 2002), USUV has been shown to be path- ogenic only for birds with the exception of a human case characterized by fever and skin rash (Adam and Digoutte, 2007). In Austrian endemic areas, no cases were reported in either domestic animals or humans (Weissenböck et al., 2003). Furthermore, in this study, no evidence of disease was observed in seropositive horses. The presented results demonstrate the circulation of USUV in north-eastern Italy in local birds and mosqui- toes. Whether this could be an evidence of the establish- ment of an endemic infection cycle cannot be ascertained yet. Should this be the case however avian mortality in the forthcoming years can be expected in the wild bird populations, in particular blackbirds. It is worthwhile to note that the area where the USUV chicken seroconver- sions occurred is nearby that where episodes of Chikun- gunya happened (Angelini et al., 2007). The Chikungunya virus was transmitted by Aedes albopictus, which, although is not one of the most important, but is still a potential vector of USUV. It could be concluded that events, such as the one just described are indicators of possible emerging threats in Europe owing to vector-borne agents for which the impact on animal and human health is at present difficult to assess. column2: Serologic Evidence of West Nile Virus Infections in Wild Birds Captured in Germany Sonja Linke, Matthias Niedrig, Andreas Kaiser, Heinz Ellerbrok, Kerstin Müller, Thomas Müller, Franz Josef Conraths, Ralf-Udo Mühle, Daniel Schmidt, Ulrich Köppen, Franz Bairlein, Peter Berthold, and Georg Pauli* Zentrum für Biologische Sicherheit 1, Robert Koch-Institut, Berlin, Germany; Department V (Ecology), Institute for Zoology, University of Mainz, Mainz, Germany; Department of Veterinary Medicine, Small Animal Clinic, Freie Universität Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Friedrich-Loeffler-Institute, Federal Research Institute for Animal Health, Institute for Epidemiology, Wusterhausen, Germany; Ökologische Station Gülpe, Universität Potsdam, Potsdam, Germany; NABU Center for Bird Protection, Mössingen, Germany; Landesamt für Umwelt, Naturschutz und Geologie Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Beringungszentrale, Greifswald, Germany; Institute of Avian Research, Vogelwarte Helgoland, Wilhelmshaven, Germany; Max Planck Research Centre of Ornithology, Vogelwarte Radolfzell, Radolfzell, Germany Abstract. To assess the risk of acquiring a West Nile virus (WNV) infection in Germany, we investigated samples from migrating and from resident birds. Because of their stay in or migration through WNV-endemic regions, these birds are at risk to become infected with WNV. Blood samples from 3,399 birds, representing 87 bird species, were collected in Germany in 2000 and in 2002–2005. Overall, 53 birds belonging to 5 species had WNV-neutralizing antibodies. Fifty-nine birds belonging to 9 species were reactive by WNV immunofluorescence assay, and 8 birds had neutralizing antibodies against Usutu virus. Because of maternal antibody transfer via egg yolk, WNV-antibody titers in white stork nestlings were generally lower than those in adults. Despite a relatively high percentage of stork nestlings with anti- bodies, no viral genomes were detectable by polymerase chain reaction. In Germany, the prevalence of antibodies to WNV in migrating birds wintering in Africa or southern Europe is comparatively low. INTRODUCTION Within the genus Flavivirus of the family Flaviviridae, West Nile virus (WNV) and Usutu virus (USUV) are grouped to the Japanese encephalitis antigen group. West Nile virus is endemic in different parts of the world, whereas USUV seems to be endemic only in Africa and possibly in Austria.1,2 After its introduction into New York City in 1999, WNV gained worldwide interest. In the immunologically naive host popu- lation, it has spread rapidly across North America and has had an enormous impact not only on avian and equine species but also on humans, especially in the United States. West Nile virus is transmitted naturally by ornithophilic mosquitoes (particularly species of the genus Culex) within the bird popu- lation, but some mosquitoes are also capable of transmitting the virus to mammals such as horses or humans.3,4 The virus has been found in more than 150 species of wild and domestic birds in the United States.5 Millions of birds migrate every year between Europe and Africa, wintering in or passing through WNV-endemic areas. Bird migration seems to play a major role in the dissemina- tion of WNV and USUV.6,7 In Europe, antibodies to WNV have been detected in several bird species.8,9 In the United Kingdom, investigations on the prevalence and incidence of WNV infections were carried out in 2001–2002 and showed that migrating and resident birds had antibodies to WNV or viral genomes.10 In France, virus isolation was successful in various samples from mammals such as horses.3 There are no data on endogenous WNV and USUV infections in Germany, whereas USUV infections have been diagnosed in neighbor- ing Austria.2 The aim of the present study was to investigate migrating and resident birds as a potential reservoir of WNV and USUV by using serologic and molecular methods, and to assess the possibility that migrating species import these vi- ruses from their wintering areas in Africa. MATERIALS AND METHODS Bird capture and sampling. In 2000 and in 2002–2005 3,399 samples, representing 87 species of migrating and resident birds (Table 1), were collected in the context of bird-ringing activities or other research interests. The birds were captured by traps and mist nets, bled, and released or downed in pest- control programs. Sampling of white stork nestlings and rap- tor nestlings was performed by bleeding nestlings at nest sites. Morphologic examinations were performed to determine sex, age, and species. Rings engraved with a serial number from German ringing centers were used for individual marking. Several samples were collected from injured wild birds during veterinary care. National laws and regulations regarding pro- tection, conservation, and animal welfare were respected. Study sites. The study sites were spread all over Germany and located in rural or agricultural areas (Figure 1). Sampling. Blood was obtained by puncturing the vena ul- naris. The volume of blood was variable depending on the bird species (between 10 �L and 1 mL). Blood was collected in microtubes for serum separation (Sarstedt, Nuembrecht, Germany), in monovettes containing EDTA (Sarstedt), or in reaction tubes with anticoagulant preservative buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1.0 M NaCl, 0.1% Tween 20). Body fluids from dead birds were collected from the carcasses. Sera and plasma were stored at -70°C until use. Diagnostic assays. Two methods were used for serologic diagnosis: an indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) and a neutralization test (NT). The first screening was done using a WNV IFA kit (EUROIMMUN, Lübeck, Germany) following the manufacturer’s instructions. The samples were diluted 1: 10 with sampling buffer and 25 �L of the diluted samples were applied to a biochip slide and incubated for 30 minutes at room temperature. After the slide was washed for 10 min- utes, a non-labeled rabbit anti-dove IgG hyperimmune serum diluted 1:300 was added to the biochips and incubated for 30 minutes. The rabbit anti-dove IgG reacted with a broad spec- trum of antibodies derived from different bird species (Grund C, unpublished data). After a second washing step, 25 �L of * Address correspondence to Georg Pauli, Robert Koch-Institut, Nordufer 20, 13353 Berlin, Germany. E-mail: paulig@rki.de Am. J. Trop. Med. BIRDS IN GERMANY 359 a mixture of a goat anti-bird fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)–labeled antibody (Bethyl Inc., Montgomery, AL) di- luted 1:50 in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) plus Tween 20 and an anti-rabbit FITC-labeled antibody (Dianova, Ham- burg, Germany) for detection of the rabbit anti-dove IgG hyper immune serum diluted 1:300 were applied to the bio- chips. After a second incubation for 30 minutes and a washing step, the slide was embedded with a drop of glycerol/PBS according to the manufacturer’s instructions and analyzed un- der a fluorescence microscope (Axioskop MC80, filters 495 nm and 528 nm; Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany). Reactive samples were titrated in dilution steps of 1:10, 1:100, and 1: 1000 according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Reference goose serum with a known titer of antibodies to WNV was used as a control sample. The method of choice for flavivirus diagnostics and differ- entiation is the virus NT. A WNV-specific NT was performed in a 96-well plate format (Nunc, Wiesbaden, Germany). Vero cells were grown in Eagle’s minimal essential medium (MEM) (PAA Laboratories, Coelbe, Germany) supple- mented with 10% fetal bovine serum (PAA Laboratories) in 96-well microtiter plates. Samples were diluted 1:10 in PBS. The stock solution of WNV strain Israel was diluted in Ea- gle’s MEM with 1% ciprofloxacin (PAA Laboratories) to a constant concentration of 500 50% tissue culture infective doses (TCID50)/mL. A total of 25 �L of virus suspension were mixed with 25 �L of serum or plasma dilution and in- cubated for 1 hour at 37°C. After incubation, the inoculum of serum and virus was added to the cells and incubated for 3 days at 37°C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2. The suspension of plasma and virus was then removed from the cells and 100 �L of fresh medium were added to each well and incubated for 3 days at 37°C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2. After incubation, the cells were fixed and stained with naphthalene black and analyzed under a light microscope. Neutralizing goose sera were included in all experiments. Each test sample was inves- tigated in duplicate with a single well of serum-cell control without virus. Samples with neutralizing antibodies at a dilu- tion of 1:10 were titrated (two-fold serial dilutions from 1:10 to 1:2,560) to determine end point titers for WNV. Antibody titers were determined as the highest dilution of serum or plasma at which 50% of the wells did not show a cytopathic effect. Samples with a WNV antibody titer � 10 were con- sidered positive because serum dilutions < 1:10 were often toxic for cells. Some samples were further investigated in a USUV- specific plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT). The test FIGURE 1. Map of Germany showing different sampling sites. Numbers in ellipses indicate the number of captured birds. TABLE 1 Continued* Order Common name Species Samples investigated by NT † Samples investigated by IFA Migration status Passeriformes Robin Erithacus rubecula 22 160 RMW Thrush nightingale Luscinia luscinia 1 1 M Nightingale Luscinia megarhynchos 0 18 M Bluethroat Luscinia svecica 0 13 M Black redstart Phoenicurus ochruros 0 31 M Redstart Phoenicurus phoenicurus 9 52 M Dunnock Prunella modularis 4 36 RMW House sparrow Passer domesticus 0 41 R Tree sparrow Passer montanus 0 43 R Tree pipit Anthus trivialis 14 31 M Yellow wagtail Motacilla flava 1 41 M White wagtail Motacilla alba 1 2 MW Chaffinch Fringilla coelebs 2 35 RMW Bullfinch Pyrrhula pyrrhula 0 24 RMW Common crossbill Loxia curvirostra 0 13 RMW Greenfinch Carduelis chloris 0 154 RMW Siskin Carduelis spinus 0 1 RMW Yellowhammer Emberiza citrinella 0 2 RMW Ortolan bunting Emberiza hortulana 0 1 M Reed bunting Emberiza schoeniclus 0 5 MW * NT � neutralization test; IFA � indirect immunofluorescence assay; R � resident; M � migratory; W � winter guest; A � anomaly in Germany, since 1980 less than 5 individuals were verified.11,12 † Number tested in IFA is not always identical with the number of samples tested in NT because of too low amounts of sample volume or high toxicity of the sample in cell culture. LINKE AND OTHERS360 procedure was performed according to published studies13,14 with slight modifications. The test was performed in 48-well microtiter plates (Nunc) with Vero cells cultivated in Eagle’s MEM (PAA Laboratories) with 10% fetal bovine serum (PAA Laboratories) and 1% ciprofloxacin (PAA Laborato- ries). The serum or plasma samples were diluted two-fold from 1:10 to 1:640 in PBS. Aliquots (50 �L) of USUV strain Vienna 2001 from Austria containing 150 TCID50/mL were added to 50 �L of the sample and incubated for 1 hour at 37°C. The virus-sample suspension was applied to the cells and incubated for 1 hour at 37°C. After incubation, the mix- ture of plasma and virus was removed from the cell layer and fresh medium was added. An overlay of carboxymethyl cel- lulose medium (BDH Ltd., Poole, United Kingdom) was added to the cells and the cells were incubated at 37°C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2 for 3 days. The plates were fixed and stained with naphthalene black. Plaques were counted and the 50% PRNT (PRNT50) titer was calculated according to Reed and Münch.15 Viral RNA was isolated from 552 samples from white storks; 100 �L of plasma was centrifuged for 1.5 hours at 14,000 rpm. The pellet was used for virus extraction and the supernatant was used for serologic testing. RNA extraction was performed using the Qiagen RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany). RNA was eluted in 60 �L of RNase-free water (Fluka Chemikalien GmbH, Buchs, Switzerland) supplemented with RNA (100 ng/�L) (Roche, Mannheim, Germany). RNA was stored at −70°C before further use. cDNA was synthesized by reverse transcription of 11.6 �L of extracted RNA in a 20-�L reaction volume. For transcrip- tion, 1 �L of the specific reverse primer (10 �M; Table 2) and 1 �L of reverse transcriptase (200 U/�L) (Invitrogen, Karlsruhe, Germany) were used. The cDNA was stored at −20°C before further use. Reverse transcription–polymerase chain reaction (RT- PCR) was performed on a gene sequence of the capsid pro- tein and 5�-untranslated region using the TaqMan method (Table 2). As an internal control standard of the RNA ex- traction, of cDNA synthesis, and PCR, plasma was spiked with a constant volume of heat-inactivated supernatant of Squirrel monkey retrovirus (SMRV), family Retroviridae. A specific RT-PCR using the SMRV envelope protein sequence was established (Table 2). RESULTS Serum or plasma samples (n � 3,399) were collected in 2000–2005. They were derived from 87 different species; spe- cifically in 2000, 41 samples from passerine birds were col- lected; in 2002, 1,175 samples from passerine birds and wa- terfowl; in 2003, 438 blood samples from White Storks; in 2004, 1,504 samples from white stork nestlings, passerine birds, and raptors; and in 2005, 241 samples from white storks and raptors, including 106 samples from nestlings and 32 from adult ospreys. Antibodies against WNV were detected using IFA in nine species (Table 3). Washed samples were analyzed by a WNV NT, neutralizing antibodies to WNV were detected in five species (Table 3). Fifty-nine blood samples from birds had antibodies to WNV by IFA, 27 of which were also positive in the NT. Using the NT, 24 additional sera were identified that were not reactive by IFA. Because of the small amount of blood from passerine birds, the WNV NT could only be carried out on 191 samples. How- ever, because of the high cytotoxic effect of these samples, only 45 samples gave a reliable result. Of all passeriformes investigated, nine samples were positive by IFA and seven of these samples had neutralizing antibodies (Table 3). On the basis of the IFA results, the percentage of samples with an- tibodies to WNV was low. Thirty-three (5.8%) of 569 Ciconia ciconia samples were reactive by WNV IFA, and only 13 (2.3%) samples were positive by WNV NT. Three sera from Cygnus olor showed neutralizing activity, but these sera TABLE 2 Oligonucleotide primers and TaqMan probe for reverse transcription–polymerase chain reaction of WNV and SMRV* Sequence (5� → 3�) of primer and TaqMan probe Orientation‡ Genome position WNV: AY532665, SMRV: M23385 ProC-F1 CCTgTgTgAgCTgACAAACTTAgT S 10–33 ProC-R gCgTTTTAgCATATTgACAgCC AS 132–153 ProC-TM† 6FAM-CCTggTTTCTTAgACATCgAgATCTXCgTgCp AS 89–113 SMRV-7489 F CCT gCT AgT Agg ATT ggg TgT CTC T S 7489–7513 SMRV-7658 R CTA CTT Cgg CTA ggg AAT CTA gTT g AS 7634–7658 SMRV-env-probe 6FAM-TAA CgA CgT CCA AgC CTT gTC Tag CAC CAXT-p S 7588–7617 * WNV � West Nile virus; SMRV � squirrel monkey retrovirus. † X � carboxytetramethylrhodamine; FAM � 6�-carboxyfluorescein; p � phosphate. ‡ S � sense; AS � antisense. TABLE 3 Number of avian species tested positive for antibodies to West Nile virus (WNV) by IFA and NT* Taxon/species No. tested in IFA No. WNV IFA reactive No. tested in NT† No. WNV NT positive Passeriformes Erithacus rubecula 160 1 1 – Ficedula hypoleuca 24 2 2 2 Phoenicurus phoenicurus 52 2 2 1 Lanius collurio 26 2 3 3 Motacilla flava 41 1 1 – Sylvia borin 149 1 1 1 Ciconiiformes Ciconia ciconia 569 33 556 13 Falconiformes Pandion haliaetus 140 16 140 28 Milvus migrans 1 – 1 1 Haliaeetus albicilla 36 1 36 – Accipiter gentilis 19 – 19 1 Anseriformes Cygnus olor 135 – 135 3 * IFA � indirect immunofluorescence assay; NT � neutralization test. † Number of analyzable samples. ANTIBODIES TO WNV IN BIRDS IN GERMANY 361 showed negative results in the WNV IFA. Sixteen (11.4%) of 140 sera of Pandion haliaetus were reactive in the WNV IFA. In neutralization assays, the number of positive sera was higher (n � 28, 20%). Only one serum each of samples from Haliaeetus albicilla (n � 36), Milvus migrans (n � 1), and Accipiter gentilis (n � 19) had neutralizing antibodies to WNV. To gain insight into the potential cross reactivity of bird- infecting flaviviruses, 25 samples reactive against WNV in the IFA but negative in the NT were investigated in the USUV NT. Three samples were positive and had PRNT50 titers of 17, 21, and 37, respectively. The antibody titers against WNV varied in different serologic test systems and among the indi- viduals of the species. Tables 4 and 5 show that antibody titers determined using IFA and NT were generally lower in nest- lings than in adults (titers of adult white storks were 3-fold to 100-fold higher than in nestlings). In ospreys, only one nest- ling bird of 106 samples tested was reactive in WNV IFA but not in WNV NT; all other reactive samples were from adult birds. To clarify whether nestling and adult white storks were infected with WNV, 551 samples were investigated with a WNV-specific RT-PCR. No amplification of viral genomes was observed in the sera or plasma. As an internal control, SMRV was added to each sample as an RNA extraction and PCR control. No inhibition in the process of extraction, cDNA synthesis, and PCR was observed. Regarding the importation of WNV from Africa to Ger- many, bird species with WNV-specific antibodies were corre- lated with their migration status. Five species, most of which were migratory birds, had antibodies against WNV. While C. ciconia, M. migrans, and P. haliaetus migrate to tropical Africa, birds of the species Cygnus olor show a more complex migration behavior. Accipiter gentilis is a resident bird spe- cies, whereas birds of the species Cygnus olor are partial mi- grants. DISCUSSION In Germany, only limited information on the prevalence and incidence of WNV infections is available. In a study from Israel, white storks from Germany had WNV-neutralizing an- tibodies and juveniles on the migration route to Africa pass- ing Israel were diagnosed with WNV.6 The questions arose where white storks acquire the infection and whether there is evidence that WNV is present in Germany. We investigated the presence of antibodies to WNV in migrating and resident birds in different parts of Germany. A variety of migratory birds that breed in central Europe use African-Eurasian mi- gration routes, which are discussed as routes for importing WNV or other flaviviruses such as USUV into Europe.6,16 Birds seropositive for WNV were identified across Germany, demonstrating that there is no hotspot of birds with WNV (Figure 1). We identified 5 of 87 species with neutralizing antibodies, 3 of which can be correlated with wetland habi- tats. In most of the bird species, the percentage with neutral- izing antibodies was low, with the exception of ospreys. We detected specific antibodies in adults and in nestlings. The antibody titer of the nestlings most likely reflects the maternal antibody status because it is well known that mater- nal antibodies to WNV are transmitted from the mother dur- ing egg production.17,18 We investigated nestlings of ospreys and white storks at 2–9 weeks of age, but only one osprey had TABLE 4 Antibody titers of bird sera by West Nile virus IFA* Species IFA titer Total10 32 50 80 100 320 500 1,000 Haliaeetus albicilla – – – – – – 1 – 1 Pandion haliaetus Adults – 3 – – 10 1 – 1 15 Nestlings – – – – 1 – – – 1 Total – 3 – – 11 1 – 1 16 Ciconia ciconia Adults – – – – – 1 – 1 2 Nestlings 12 17 – – 2 – – – 31 Total 12 17 – – 2 1 – 1 33 Sylvia borin – – – – 1 – – – 1 Motacilla flava 1 – – – – – – – 1 Lanius collurio – – 1 – – – – 1 2 Ficedula hypoleuca – – 2 – – – – – 2 Erithacus rubecula – – – – 1 – – – 1 Phoenicurus phoenicurus 1 1 – – – – – – 2 * Values are number of reactive birds. IFA � indirect immunofluorescence assay. TABLE 5 Antibody titers of bird sera by West Nile virus neutralization test* Species NT titer Total10 15 20 30 40 80 160 240 320 640 1,280 2,560 Pandion haliaetus Adults 3 – 2 1 3 6 3 3 6 1 – – 28 Nestlings – – – – – – – – – – – – – Total 3 – 2 1 3 6 3 3 6 1 – – 28 Ciconia ciconia Adults 1 – – – – – 1 – – – 1 – 3 Nestlings 2 7 – 1 – – – – – – – – 10 Total 3 7 – 1 – – 1 – – – 1 – 13 Cygnus olor 3 – – – – – – – – – – – 3 Accipiter gentilis 1 – – – – – – – – – – – 1 Milvus migrans – – – – – 1 – – – – – – 1 Ficedula hypoleuca 1 1 – – – – – – – – – – 2 Lanius collurio 1 – 1 – – – – – – – – – 2 Phoenicurus phoenicurus 1 – – – – – – – – – – – 1 * Values are number of positive birds. LINKE AND OTHERS362 antibodies to WNV by the IFA. In contrast, we detected neu- tralizing antibodies in adult birds living in the same region. However, we found a higher percentage of WNV-specific an- tibodies in nestlings of white storks. These results either re- flect differences in the transmission of WNV-specific antibod- ies via egg yolk or differences in the half-life of maternal antibodies in the offspring. There is limited information on the persistence of maternal antibodies against WNV in birds, which complicates interpretation of serologic results.18 Viral genomes were not detected in nestling nor adult white storks by PCR, which implies that the antibody response observed in the birds seems to be an indirect marker of the serologic status of the parent birds. The serologic data obtained by IFA and NT were not con- gruent in all cases. It is well known that there is high cross- reactivity of closely related flaviviruses in antigen detection systems such as the IFA and an enzyme-linked immunosor- bent assay.19 The method of choice for detecting antibodies against flaviviruses is the NT, but cross-reacting antibodies have also been observed in this assay. High titers of neutral- izing antibodies may represent cross-reacting antibodies from flaviviruses, especially of the Japanese encephalitis serocom- plex. Differences in antibody titers against different flavivirus isolates can give further information on the virus responsible for the reduction of the immune response. The NT procedure used is very stringent and used a 100% knockout of virus infectivity for antibody detection. Under these highly de- manding conditions, it could be assumed that antibodies to WNV were acquired through exposure to WNV. Three samples of C. ciconia, Phoenicurus phoenicurus, and P. haliaetus showed positive results in the WNV IFA and had low-level neutralizing antibody titers to USUV. Findings on the emergence of USUV in Austria, which was probably in- troduced by migrating birds, showed that in the summer of 2001 several bird species were infected with USUV, and the epidemic, especially in blackbirds, was stable for more than one summer in a central European region.2 Little is known about WNV infections in wild birds in cen- tral Europe. There are limited data on the WNV seropreva- lence in passerine birds in Poland, indicating that it is at a low level.8 A study of WNV infections in Austria did not detect WNV in dead wild birds, and the investigators concluded that WNV has no measurable impact in Austria.20 However, in the United Kingdom serologic evidence for WNV and USUV was reported in wild resident and migrating birds, as well as in sentinel chickens.21 Detection of the WNV genome was dem- onstrated in crows.10 In our study, none of 41 Corvidae samples showed evidence of an antibody response to WNV. Infections with WNV in migratory birds in Europe can oc- cur either through exposure in Europe, on migratory routes, or at wintering sites in Africa. The sporadic outbreaks of WNV infections in areas in southern Europe such as Roma- nia, Tuscany in Italy, and Camargue in France do not support the assumption that WNV is endemic in these regions but may indicate that WNV is occasionally imported to these ar- eas. In tracking the migratory route of birds from Europe to Africa, it is noteworthy that there are two major destinations, one to western regions of Africa and the other to eastern parts of Africa. On the route via southeastern Europe it was observed that WNV epidemics occur in countries such as Ro- mania and Israel.22–24 Many bird species rest in Israel before or after the flight across the desert during autumn and spring migration.6 Sporadic introduction of WNV by migrating birds to central Europe may therefore be possible. However, there are limited data on the viremic phase in WNV-infected birds. In experimental infections of different bird species, viremia in birds was high for approximately four days to enable infection of mosquitoes.25 It is doubtful whether this period is long enough for direct import of the virus from disease-endemic areas in Africa to central Europe. However, infections with USUV in Austria support the as- sumption that flavivirus infections might be imported and maintained in temperate regions.2 It remains unclear why there is a low level percentage of antibodies to WNV in European migrating birds without clear evidence of WNV-diseased birds. In contrast to birds in the United States showing clinical symptoms, European birds have long been exposed to WNV on their migration routes to and from Africa. Over centuries, this exposure might have induced a natural resistance to WNV infections in European birds, whereas in America WNV was introduced into a highly susceptible bird population that had never been exposed to this virus. There is evidence of only a few human WNV infections imported from the United States into Germany. Because of climate warming, it must be assumed that further WNV in- fections limited in time and region might appear, similar to the current situation in southeastern Europe.
